div.p:
A NEW METHOD OF Rosie Crucian phyick: Wherein is hewed the Caue; and therewith their experienced Medicines for the Cure of all DISEASES,
< in non-Latin alphabet > ; Freely given to the inpired CHRISTIANS, BY < in non-Latin alphabet > .
And in obedience fitted for the undertanding of mean capacities by the Adorer, and the mot unworthy of their LOVE, John Heydon, a Servant of God, and Secretary of Nature.
London Printed for Thomas Lock, 1658.

div.head: An Apologue for an Epilogue.
div.p: I Shall here tel you what Roie Crucians are, and that Moes was their Father, and he was < in non-Latin alphabet > ; ome ay they were of the order of Elias, ome ay the Diciples of Ezekiel, others define them to be < in non-Latin alphabet > ; i.e. The Officers of the Generaliimo of the world, that are as the eyes and cares of the great King, eeing & hearing all things; they are Seraphically illuminated, as Moes was according to this order of the Elements, earth refin'd to water, water to air, air to fire; o of a man to be one of the Heroes of a Heros, a Daemon, or good genius, of a genius, a partaker of Divine things, and a companion of the holy company of unbodied ouls and immortall Angels, and according to their vehicles, a veratile life, turning themelves Proteus-like into any hape.

But there is yet arguments to procure Mr. Walfoord, and T. Williams, Roie Crucians by election, and that is the miracles that were done by them, in any ight; for it hould eeme Roie Crucians were not only initiated into the Moaicall Theory, but have arrived alo to the power of working miracles as Moes, Elias, Ezekiel and the ucceeding Prophets did, as being tranported where they pleae, as Habakkuk was from Jewry to Babylon or as Philip after he had baptized the Enuch to Arotus, and one of thee went from me to a friend of mine in Devonhire, and came and brought me an anwer to London the ame day, which is four dayes journey, they taught
me excellent predictions of Atrologie, and earthquakes; they lack the plague in Cityes; they ilence the violent winds and tempets; they calme the rage of the Sea and rivers; they walk in the Air, they frutrate the Malicious apect of Witches; they cure all dieaes; I deired one of thee to tell me whether my complexion were capable of the ociety of my good Genius? when I ee you again, aid he, I will tell you (which is) (when he pleaes to come to me, for I know not where to go to him) when I aw him then he aid Ye hould pray to God, for a good and holy man can offer no greater nor more acceptable acrifice to God, then the oblation of himelf, his oul.

He aid alo that the good Genii are as the benigne eyes of God, running to and fro in the world, with love and pitty beholding the innocent endeavours of harmles and ingle hearted men, ever ready to do them good, and to help them; and at his going away he bid me beware of my eeming friends who would do me all the hurt they could, and caue the Governors of the Nations to be angry with me, and et bounds to my liberty, which truly hapned to me, as they did indeed: many things more he told me before we parted, but I hall not name them here.

For this Roie Crucian Phyick or Medicines, I happily and unexpectedly light upon in Arabia, which will prove a retauration of health to all that are afflicted wh that icknes, which we ordinarily cal natural, & all other dieaes, as the Gour, Dropie, Leproie and falling icknes; and thee men may be aid to have no mall inight in the body, and that Walfoord, Williams, and others of the Fraternity now living, may bear up in the ame likely Equipage, with thoe noble Divine pirits their predecesors, though the unskilfullnes in men commonly acknowledge more of upernaturall aitance
in hot unetled fancies, and perplexed melancholy, then in the calme and ditinct ue of reaon; yet for mine own part, but not without ubmiion to better judgements, I looke upon thee Roie Crucians above all men truly inpired, and more than any that profeed or pretended themelves o, this ixteen hundred yeares, and I am ravihed with admiration of their miracles and trancendent mechanicall inventions, for the alving the Phaenomena in the world; I may without offence therefore compare them with Bezaliel and Aholiab, thoe skilfull and cunning workers of the tabernacle, who, as Moes tetifies, were filled with the pirit of God, and therefore were of an excellent undertanding to find out all manner of curious work.

Nor is it any more argument, that thee Roie Crucians are not inpired, becaue they do not ay they are; then that others are inpired, becaue they ay they are; which to me is no argument at all; but the uppreion of what o hapned, would argue much more obriety & modety; whenas the profeion of it with ober men, would be upected of ome peice of melancholy and ditraction, epecially in thee things, where the grand pleaure is the evidence and exercie of reaon, not a bare beliefe, or an ineffable ene of life, in repect whereof there is no true chritian but he is inpired; but if any more zealous pretender to prudence and righteounes, wanting either leaure or ability to examine thee Roie Crucian Medicines to the bottom hall notwithtanding either condemn them or admire them; he hath unbecommingly and indicreetly vetered out of his own phere, and I cannot acquit him of injutice or folly: Nor am I a Roie Crucian, nor do I peake of pite, or hope of gain, or for any uch matter; there is no caue, God knows, I envie no man, be he what he will be, I am no phyitian, never was, nor never mean to be: what I am it
makes no matter as to my profeion.

Latly, thee holy and good men would have me know that the greatet weet and perfection of a vertuous oul, is the kindly accomplihment of her own nature, in true widom and divine love; and thee miraculus things that are done by them are, that that worth and knowledge that is in them may be taken notice of, and that God thereby may be glorified whoe witnees they are; but no other happines accrues to them from this, but that hereby they may be in a better capacity of makeing others happy,

div.head: A New METHOD OF Roie Crucian Phyick.
CHAP. I.

argument.p: Of the Accurate Structure of Mans body.

div.p:
I Admire the goodnes of God towards us in the frame and tructure of our bodies, the admirable Artifice whereof, Galen, though a Naturalit, was o taken with, that he could not but adjudge the honor of a hymn to the wie Creator of it. The continuance of the whole, and every particular, is o evident an Argument of exquiite skill in the Maker, that if I hould purue all that utes to my purpoe, it would amount to too large (yet an entire) Volume. I hall therefore write all that is needful to be known by all men, leaving the ret to be upply'd by Anatomists: And I think there is no man that hath any skill in that Art, but will confes, the more diligently and accurately the frame of our body is examined, it is found the more exquiitely conformable to our Reaon, Judgement, and Deire; o that uppoing
the ame matter that our bodies are made of, if it had been in our own power to have made our elves, we hould have fram'd our elves no otherwie then we are: To intance in ome particulars; As in our Eyes, the Number, the Scituation, the Fabrick of them is uch, that we can excogitate nothing to be added thereto, or to be altered, either for their beauty, afety, or uefulnes; but as for their beauty, I have treated largely of it in my youthful merry Poems, & now am not minded to trancribe my tender nice ubject, and couple it with my everer tile; I will onely note how afely they are guarded, and fitly framed out for the ue they are intended: The Brow and the Noe aves them from harder trokes; but uch a curious part as the Eye being necearily liable to michief from mallet matters, the weat of the Forehead is fenced off by thoe two Wreaths of Hair which we call the Eye-brows; and the Eye-lids are fortified with little tiff britles, as with Palliadoes, againt the aault of Flyes and Gnats, and uch-like bold Animalcula; beides, the upper-lid preently claps down, and is as good a Fence as a Port-Cullis againt the importunity of the Enemy; which is done alo every night, whether there be any preent aault or no, as if nature kept Garrion in this Acropolis of mans body, the Head, and look'd that uch Laws hould be duly oberved, as were mot for his afety.

And now for the ue of the Eye, which is ight, it is evident that this Organ is o exquiitely framed for that purpoe, that not the leat curioity can be added: For firt, the Humor and Tunicles are purely tranparent to let in light, and colours unfould, and unophiticated by any inward tincture. And then again, the parts of the Eye are made convex, that there might be a direction of many raies coming from one point of the object, unto one point anwerable in the bottom of the eye; to which purpoe the Chrytalline humor is of great moment, and without which, the ight would be very obcure and weak. Thirdly, The Tunica uvea hath a Muculous Power, and can dilate and contract that round hole in it which is called the Pupil of the Eye, for the better moderating the tranmiion of light. Fourthly, The inide
of the uvea is blacked like the Wall of a Tennis-Court, the raies falling upon the Retina again; for uch a repercuion would make the ight more confued. Fifthly, The Tanica Arachnoides, which invellops the Chrytalline Humour, by vertue of its Proceus Ciliaros, can thrut forward, or draw back that precious ueful part of the Eye, as the nearnes or ditance of the objects hall require. Sixthly and latly, The Tunica Retina is white, for the better and more true reception of the pecies of things, (as they ordinarily call them) as white paper is fittet to receive thoe Images into a dark room; and the eye is already o perfect, that I believe it is not needful to peak any more thereof; we being able to move our head upwards and downwards, and on every ide, might have unawares thought our elves ufficiently well provided for; but Nature hath added Mucles alo to the Eyes, that no perfection might be wanting; for we have oft occaion to move our Eyes, our Heads being unmoved, as in reading, and viewing more particularly any object et before us; and that this may be done with more eae and accuracy, he hath furnihed that Organ with no lee then ix everal Mucles; and indeed, this framing of Mucles, not onely in the Eye, but in the whole body, is admirable; for is it not a wonder that even all our fleh hould be o handomly formed and contrived into ditinct pieces, whoe rie and inertions hould be with uch advantage that they do erve to move ome part of the body or other? and that the parts of our body are not moved onely o conveniently as wil erve us to walk and ubit by, but that they are able to move every way imaginable that will advantage us; for we can fling out Legs and Arms upwards and downwards, backwards, forwards, and round, as they that pin, or would pread a Mole-hill with their feet. To ay nothing of Repiration, the contriction of the Diaphragme for the keeping down the Guts, and o enlarging the Thorax, that the Lungs may have play, and the aitance of the inward intercotal Mucles in deep upirations, when we take more large gulps of air to cool our heart over-charged with love or orrow; nor of the curious Fabrick of the Lainix, o well fitted with Mucles for
the modulation of the Voice, tunable peech, and delicious inging: You may adde to thee the notable contrivance of the Heart, its two ventricles, and its many valvulae, o fram'd and cituated, as is mot fit for the reception and tranmiion of the blood, and it's ent thence away warm to comfort and cherih the ret of the body; for which purpoe alo the valvulae in the veins are made.

But we ee by experience that joy and grief proceed not in all men from the ame caues, and that men differ very much in the contitution of the body, whereby that which helpeth and furthereth vital contitution in one, and is therefore delightful, hindereth & croeth it in another, and therefore caueth grief. The difference therefore of Wits, hath its original from the different paions, & from the ends to which the appetite leadeth them. As for that difference which arieth from icknes, and uch accidental ditempers, I have appointed them for the econd Part of this Book, and therefore I omit the ame as impertinent to this place, and conider it onely in uch as have their health, perfection of body, and Organs well dipoed.

div.head: CHAP. II.

argument.p: Of the perfection of the Body, and then of the Nature of the Senes; of Delight, Pain, Love, Hatred, enual Delight, and Pains of the Body, Joy, and Grief.

div.p:
OTher things I have to ay, but I will rather init upon uch things as are eaie ahd intelligible even to Idiots, or uch Phyicians that are no wier, who if they can but tell the Joints of their hands, or know the ue of their teeth, they may eaily dicover it was Counel, not Chance, that created them; and if they but undertand thee natural Medecines I have prepared in this Book for their example, they will know that they hall be cured of all Dieaes without pain, or any great cot; and Love, not Money, was it that made me undertake this Task. Now of the well-fram'd parts of our body,
I would know why we have three joints in our Legs and Arms, as alo in our fingers, but that it was much better then having but two or four? And why are our fore-teeth harp, like Chizzels, to cut, but our inward teeth broad, to grind? but this is more exquiite then having them all harp, or all broad, or the fore-teeth broad, and the other harp; but we might have made a hard hift to have lived, though in that worer condition. Again, Why are the Teeth o luckily placed? or rather, Why are there not Teeth in other bones as well as in the Jaw-bones, for they might have been as capable as thee. But the reaon is, Nothing is done foollhly, nor in vain. I will hew you how to prolong life, and to return from age to youth; and how to change, alter, and amend the state of the body; but that I intend in a Treatie entituled The Wie Mans Crown: To keep the body in perfect health is my preent deign, and to cure all Dieaes without reward; for there is a Divine Providence that orders all things. Again, (to ay nothing of the inward curioity of the Ear) Why is that outward frame of it, but that it is certainly known that it's for the bettering of our hearing?

I might add, That Nature hath made the hind-mot parts of our body (which we it upon) mot flehy, as providing for our eae, making us a Natural Cuhion, as well as for Intruments of Motion for our Thighs and Legs; he hath made the hinder part of the Head more trong, as being otherwie unfenced againt falls and other caualties. She hath made the Backbon of everal Vertebrae, as being more fit to bend, more tough, and les in danger of breaking then if they were all one intire bone, without thoe gritly Junctures. She hath trengthened our fingers and toes with Nailes, whereas he might have ent out that ubtance at the end of the firt and econd Joints, which had not been o handom and ueful, nay, rather omewhat troubleome and hurtful. And latly, She hath made all bones devoid of ene, becaue they were to bear the weight of themelves, and of the whole body; and therefore if they had had ene, our life had been painful continually, and dolorous.

And now I have conidered the fitnes of the parts of mans bodie for the good of the whole, let me but conider briefly his ences and his nature, and then I intend more olidly to demontrate the caue of all Dieaes, and with that the Cure, becaue I intend a Method of Roie Crucian Phyick, promied in my way to Blie. By our everal Organs, we have everal Conceptions of everal qualities in the objects; for by ight we have a conception or image compoed of colour and figure, which is all the notice and knowledge the object imparteth to us of its nature, by the excellency of the eye. By Hearing we have a conception called Sound, which is all the knowledge we have of the quality of the object from the Ear: And o the ret of the Sences are alo conceptions of everal qualities or natures of their objects.

Becaue the Image in viion coniting of colour and hape, is the knowledge we have of the qualities of the object of that Sence, it is no hard matter for a man to fall into this opinion, That the ame colour & hape are the very qualities themelves; and for the ame caue that ound & noie are the qualities of a piece of Canon or Culvering charged with ulphurous Powder, fired, or of the Air: And this opinion hath been o long received, that the contrary mut needs appear a great Paradox. The ame qualities are eaier in a bell; and yet the introduction of pecies viible and intelligible, (which is neceary for the maintenance of that opinion) paing to and fro from the object, is wore then any Paradox, as being a plain imposibility. I hall therefore endeavor to make plain thee points.
That the ubject wherein colour and image are inherent; is not the object or thing een.
That there is nothing (really) which we call an Image or Colour.
That the aid Image, or Colour, is but an apparation unto us of the motion, agitation, or alteration, which the object worketh in the brain, or pirits, or ome internal ubtance of the Head.
That as in viion, o alo in conceptions that arie from the other enes, the ubject of their inherence is not the object, but the continent.

That conceptions and apparitions are nothing really, but motion in ome internal ubtance of the Head; which motion not topping there, of neceity mut there either help, or hinder the motion which is called Vital; when it helpeth it is called Delight, Contentment or Pleaure, which is nothing really but motion about the heart, as conception is nothing but motion in the head; and the objects that caue it are called Pleaant, or Delightful; and the ame Delight, with reference to the object is called Love; but when uch motion weakneth or hindreth the vital motion, then it is called Pain, and in relation to that which caueth it, Hatred.

There are two orts of pleaures, whereof one eemeth to affect the corporeal Organ of the ence, and that I call enual, the greatet part whereof is that by which we are invited to give continuance to our pecies; and the next by which a man is invited to meat, for preervation of his individual peron. The other ort of Delight is not particularly any part of the body, and is called The Delight of the mind, & is that which we call Joy. Likewie of pains, ome affect the body, and are therefore called The pains of the body; and ome not, and thoe are called grief.

div.head: CHAP. III.

argument.p: Of the nature of the Soul of Man, whether he be a meer Modification of the body, or a Subtance really ditinct; and then whether corporeal, or incorporeal, and of the temper of the bodie.

div.p:
HEre I am forced to peak what I have in my Familiar Spirit, and it is not impertinent to my purpoe; therefore if we ay that the oul is a meer modification of the body, the oul then is but one univeral faculty of the body, or a many faculties put together; and thoe operations which are uually attributed unto the oul, mut of neceity be attributed unto the body: I demand therefore, To what in the body will you attribute pontaneous motion? I undertand thereby a power
in our elves of wagging, or holding till mot of the parts of our body, as our hand uppoe, or little finger: If you will ay that it is nothing but the immiion of the pirits into uch and uch Mucles, I would gladly know what does immit thee pirits, and direct them o curiouly; is it themelves? or the brains? or that particular piece of the brain they call the Pine-Kernel? What ever it be, that which doth thus immit them, and direct them, mut have Animadverion; and the ame that hath Animadverion, hath Memory and Reaon alo: Now I would know whether the pirits themelves be capable of Animadverion, Memory, and Reaon; for it indeed eems altogether impoible; for thee animal pirits are nothing ele but matter very thin and liquid, whoe nature conits in this, that all the particles of it be in motion, and being looe from one another, frigge and play up and down according to the meaure and manner of agitation in them.

I therefore demand which of thee particles in thee o many looly moving one from another, hath Animadverion in it? if you ay that they all put together have; I appeal to him that thus anwers, how unlikely it is that that hould have Animadverion that is o utterly uncapable of Memory, and conequently, of Reaon; for it is imposible to conceive memory competible to uch a ubject, as it is how to write Characters in the Water, or in the Wind.

If you ay the Brain immits and directs thee pirits; how can that o freely and pontaneouly move it elf, or another, that hath no Mucles? Beides Doctor Culpepper tells you that though the Brain be the intrument of ence, yet it hath no ene at all of it elf; how then can that that hath no ence direct thus pontaneouly and arbitrariouly, the animal pirits in to any part of the body? an Act that plainly requires determinate ene and perception: But let the Phyicians and Anatomits conclude what they will, I hall, I think, little lee then demontrate that the brains have no ence; for the ame in us that hath ence, hath likewie animadverion; and that which hath animadverion in us, hath alo a faculty of free and arbitrarious Fancy and Reaon.

Let us now conider the nature of the brain, and ee how competible thoe alterations are to uch a ubject; verily if we take a right view of this Laxe pith or marrow in mans head, neither our ence nor undertanding can dicover any thing more in this ubtance that can pretend to uch noble operations, as free imagination and agacious collections of Reaon, then we can dicern in a lump of fat, or a pot of honey; for this looe pulpe that is thus wrapped up within our Cranium, is but a pongie and porous body, and pervious, not onely to the animal pirits, but alo to more Juice and Liquor; ele it could not well be nourihed, at leat it could not be o oft and moitned by drunkennes and exces, as to make the undertanding inept and ottih in its operations. Wherefore I now demand, in this oft ubtance which we call the brain, whoe oftnes implies that it is in ome meaure liquid, and liquidity implies a everal motion of looened parts; in what part or parcel thereof does Fancy, Reaon, and Animadverion lie? In this laxe conitence that lies like a Net, all on heaps in the water; I demand, In what Knot, Loope, or Interval thereof, does this faculty of free Fancy, and active Reaon reide? I believe not a Doctor in England, nay, not Dr. Culpepper himelf, were he alive, nor his men, Doctor Freeman, and the ret, can aign me any; and if any will ay, in all together; they mut ay that the whole brain is figured into this or that repreentation, which would cancel memory, and take away all capacity of there being any ditinct notes and places for the everal pecies of things there preented. But if they will ay there is in every part of the brain this power of Animadverion and Fancy, they are to remember that the brain is in ome meaure a liquid body, and we mut enquire how thee looe parts undertand one anothers everal Animadverions and notions; and if they could (which is yet very unconceivable) yet if they could from hence do any thing toward the immiion and direction of the animal pirits into this or that part of the body, they mut do it by knowing one anothers minds, and by a ioint contention of trength, as when many men at once, the word being given when they weigh Anchor, put their trength together for the moving of that Maie body, that the ingle trength of one could not deal with; but this is to make the everal particles of the brain o many individual
perons; a fitter object for laughter, then the leat meaure of belief.

Beides, how come thee many Animadverions to eem but one to us, our mind being thee, as is uppoed? Or why if the figuration of one part of the brain be communicated to all the ret, does not the ame object eem ituated both behind us, and before us, above, and beneath, on the right hand and on the left; and every way as the impres of the object is reflected againt all the parts of the brains? but there appearing to us but one animadverion, and one ight of things, it is a ufficient Argument that there is but one; or if there be many, that they are not mutually communicated from the parts one to another, and therefore there can be no uch joint endeavor towards one deign; whence it is manifet, that the brains cannot immit or direct thee animal pirits into what part of the body they pleae.

div.head: CHAP. IV.

argument.p: Of Spontaneous Motion; of the External Phaenomena; of the nature of the Eence of the Soul her elf, what it is, and whether it be corporeal, or incorporeal.

div.p:
NOW I mut tell you, that the brain hath no ence, & therefore cannot impres pontaneouly any motion on the animal pirits; it is no light Argument that ome being diected, have been found without brains; and this I aw, a Captain in Chriley, in Arabia that was accidentally kill'd by an Alcade, and an Arabian, the tory is pleaant, but not pertinent to our purpoe; but this man had nothing but a limpid water in his head intead of brains, and the brains generally are eaily diolvable into a watery conitence, which agrees with what I intimated before. Now I appeal to any free Judge, how likely thee liquid particles are to approve themelves of that nature and power, as to be able by erecting and knitting themelves together for a moment of time, to bear themelves o, as with one joint contention of trength, to caue an arbitrarious obligation of
the pirits into this or that determinate part of the body; but the aburdity of this I have ufficiently ininuated already.

The Nerves, I mean the Marrow of them, which is of the ame ubtance with the brain, have no ence, as is demontrated from a Catalep • e, or Cat • chus; but I will not accumulate Arguments in a matter o palpable. As for that little prunt piece of the brain which they call the Conacion, that this hould be the very ubtance, whoe natural faculty it is to move it elf, and by its motion and nods to determine the coure of the pirits into this or that part of the body, eems to me no les foolih and fabulous then the Storie of this entituled Doctor Freeman, o much commended by ignorantly innocent people: If you heard but the magnificent torie that is told of the little lurking Muhrome, how it does not onely hear and ee, but imagines, reaons, commands the whole fabrick of the body more dexterouly then an Indian Boy does an Elephant: what an acute Logician, ubtile Geometrician, prudent Stateman, skilful Phyician, and profound Philoopher he is! and then afterwards by diection you dicover this worker of miracles to be nothing but a poor illy contemptible Knob, or Protuberancy, coniting of a thin Membrane, containing a little pulpous matter, much of the ame nature with the ret of the Brain,
Would you not ooner laugh at it, then go about to confute it? and truly I may the better laugh it now, having already confuted it in what I have afore merrily argued concerning the ret of the Brain.

I hall therefore make bold to conclude, That the impres of Spontaneous Motion is neither from the animal pirits, nor from the Brain, &c. therefore that thoe operations that are uually attributed unto the oul, are really incompetible to any part of the body; and therefore, as in the lat Chapter I hinted, I ay, That the oul is not a meer modification of the body, but a ubtance ditinct therefrom.

Now we are to enquire, Whether this ubtance ditinct from what we ordinarily call the body, be alo it elf a Corporeal Subtance, or whether it be incorporeal? If you ay that it is a corporeal ubtance, you can undertand no other then matter
more ubtile and tenuious then the animal pirits themelves, mingled with them, and dipered through the veels and poroities of the body; for there can be no penetration of dimenions: But I need no new arguments to confute this fond conceit; for what I aid of the animal pirits before, is applicable with all eae and fitnes to this preent cae; and let it be ufficient that I advertie you o much, and o be excued from the repeating of the ame things over again.

It remains therefore that we conclude, That that which imprees Spontaneous Motion upon the body or more immediately upon the animal pirits: That which imagines, remembers, and reaons, is an immaterial ubtance, ditinct from the body, which ues the animal pirits and the brain for Intruments in uch and uch operations. And thus we have found a pirit in a proper notion and ignification, that hath apparently thee faculties in it, it can both undertand and move corporeal matter.

And now this prize that we have won will prove for our deign in this new Method of Phyick and Philoophy of very great conequence; for it is obvious here to oberve that the oul of man is as it were < in non-Latin alphabet > a compendious tatue of the Deity; her ubtance is a olid Eigies of God; and therefore as with eae we conider the ubtance and motion of the vat Heavens on a little Sphere, or Globe, o we may with like facility contemplate the nature of the Almighty in this little Model of God, the oul of Man, enlarging to Infinity what we oberve in our elves when we transfer it unto God, as we do imagine thee Circles which we view on the Globe, to be vatly bigger while we fancy them as decribed in the heavens.

Wherefore we being aured of this, That there is a piritual ubtance in our elves, in which both thee properties do reide, viz. of the undertanding, and of moving the corporeal matter; let us but enlarge our minds o as to conceive as well as we can of a piritual ubtance that is able to move & actuate all matter whatoever, never o far extended, and after what way & manner oever it pleae, and that it hath not onely the knowledge of this or that particular thing, but a ditinct and plenary cognizance of all things; and we have indeed a very competent apprehenion
of the nature of the eternal and inviible God, who like the oul of man, does not indeed fall under ence, but does everywhere operate o, that his peron is eaily to be gathered from what is dicovered by our outward ences.

div.head: CHAP. V.

argument.p: Of Plants; that the meer motion of the matter may do omething, yet it will not amount to the production of Plants. That it is no botch in Nature that ome Phaenomena be the reults of Motion, others of ubtantial forms. That beauty is not a meer fancy, and that the beauty and vertue of Plants is an Argument that they are made for the ue of our bodies from an intellectual principle.

div.p: HOW weak is Man if you conider his nature, what faculties he hath, and in what order he is in repect of the ret of the creatures? And indeed, though his body be but weak and diarm'd, yet his inward abilities of Reaon, and artificial contrivance, is admirable, both for finding out thoe ecret Medicines which God prepared for the ue of Man in the Bowels of the Earth, of Plants and Minerals.

And firt of Vegetables, where I hall touch onely thee four heads, their form and beauty, their eed, their ignatures, and their great ue, as well for medicines as utenance; and that we may the better undertand the advantage we have in this cloer contemplation of the works of nature, we are in the firt place to take notice of the condition of the ubtance, which we call matter, how fluid and lippery, and undeterminate it is of it elf; or if it be hard, how unfit it is to be changed into any thing ele; and therefore all things rot into a moiture before any thing can be generated of them, as we often the wax before we et on the eal.

Now therefore, unles we will be foolih, as becaue the uniform motion of the Air, or ome more ubtil corporeal Element, may o equally compres or bear againt the parts of a little vaporous moiture, as to form it into round drops (as we ee in the dew, and other experiments) and therefore becaue this
more rude and general motion can do omething, to conclude that it does all things; We mut in all reaon confes that there is an eternal Mind and Vertue, whereof the matter is thus uefully formed and changed.

But meer rude and undirected motion, becaue naturally it will have ome kind of reults, that therefore it will reach to uch as plainly imply a wie contrivance of counel, is o ridiculous a Sophim, as I have already intimated, that it is more fit to impoe upon the inconiderate ouls of fool & children, then upon men of Mature Reaon, and well exercied in Philoophy, or the grave and well practied, eraphically illuminated Roie Crucians. Admit that Rain, and Snow, and Wind, and Hail, and Ice, and Thunder, and Lightning, and a Star I mention for example, that may be let in amongt Meteors, by ome called Hellens-tar, and is well known at Sea; I have een it melt Copper Veels a-board a hip; it cometh of an heap of uch vapors as are carryed by violent cros Winds up from the Earth; and uch like Meteors may be the products of heat and cold, or of the motion and ret of certain mall particles of the matter; yet that the ueful and beautiful contrivance of the Branches, Flowers, and Fruits of Plants hould be o too, (to ay nothing yet of Minerals, and the bodies of men) is as ridiculous and upine a collection, as to infer, That becaue meer heat and cold does often and harden Wax, and puts it into ome hape or other, that therefore this meer heat and cold, or Motion and Ret, without any Art and Direction, made the Silver Seal too, and graved upon it o curiouly ome Coate of Arms, or the hape of ome Bird or Beat, as an Eagle, a Lyon, &c. nay indeed this inference is more tolerable far then the other, thee effects of Art being more eaie, and les noble then thoe other of nature.

Nor is it any deficiency at all in the Works of Nature, that ome particular Phaenomena be but the eaie reults of that general motion communicated unto the matter from God; others the effects of more curious contrivance, or of the Divine Ar • , or Reaon, (for uch are the < in non-Latin alphabet > , the Rationes Seminales) incorporated in the Matter, epecially the Matter it elf being in ome ort vital, ele it would not continue the motion that it is put upon, when it is occaionally this or the other way moved;
and beides the Nature of God being the mot perfect fulnes of life that is poibly conceiveable, it is very congruous that this outmot and remotet hadow of himelf, be ome way, though but obcurely vital: Wherefore things falling off by degrees from the highet perfection, it will be no uneven or unproportionable tep, if decending from the top of this utmot Creation, Man, in whom there is a more fine conception, or reflexive Reaon, which hangs on, as every man hath o much experience as to have een the Sun, and other viible objects by reflexion in the Water and Glaes; and this as yet hall be all I will ay for this reaon; I will give you more then I promied in the Contents, by four propoitions concerning the nature of conceptions, and they hall be proved; and alo of the main deception of ence, that Colour and Image may be there where the thing een is not: But becaue it may be aid, That notwithtanding the Image in the Water be not in the object, but a thing meerly phantatical, yet there may be colours really in the thing it elf, I will urge further this experience, That divers times men ee directly the ame object double, as two Candles for one, which may happen from ditemper, or otherwie without ditemper if a man will; the Organs being either in their right temper, or equally ditempered, the colours and images in two uch characters of the ame thing, cannot be inherent therein, becaue the thing een cannot be in two places.

One of thee Images therefore is not inherent in the Object but the eeing, the Organs of the ight are then in equal temper or ditemper, the one of them is no more inherent then the other, and conequently, neither of them both are in the Objects, which is the firt propoition mentioned in the precedent number.

Secondly, that the Image of any thing by reflexion in a glas, or water, or the like, is not any thing in, or behind the glas, or in, or under the Water, every man may grant to himelf; which is the econd propoition of Des Cartes. For thirdly We are to conider, firt, That every great agitation or concuion of the brain (as it happeneth from a troke, epecially if the troke be upon the eye) whereby the Optick Nerve uffereth any great violence, there appeareth before the Eyes a certain
light, which light is nothing without, but an apparition onely; all that is real being the concuion or motion of the parts of the Nerve; from which experience we may conclude, That apparition of light is really nothing but motion within. If therefore from Lucid bodies there can be derived motion, o as to affect the Optick Nerve in uch manner as is proper thereunto, there will follow an Image of light ome-where in that line by which the motion was lat derived to the eye, that is to ay, In the object, if we look directly on it, and in the Glas or Water, when we look upon it in the line of reflexion, which in effect is the third propoition, namely, That image and colour is but an apparition to us of that motion, agitation, or alteration, which the object worketh in the brain or pirits, or ome internal ubtance in the head.

But that from all lucid, hining, and illuminate bodies, there is a motion produced to the eye, and thorow the eye, to the Optick Nerve and o into the Brain, by which the apparition of light or colour is effected, is not hard to prove. And firt, it is evident that the Fire, the onely lucid body here upon Earth, worketh by motion equally every way, inomuch as the motion thereof topped or incloed, it is preently extinguihed, and no more fire. And further, That that motion whereby the fire worketh, is dilation and contraction of it elf alternately, commonly called Scintillation, or glowing, is manifet alo by experience; from uch motion in the fire mut needs arie a rejection, or cating from it elf off that part of the medium which is contiguous to it, whereby that part alo rejecteth the next, and o ucceively one part beateth back another to the very eye, and in the ame manner the exteriour part of the eye preeth the interiour, (the Laws of refraction till oberved.) Now the interior coat of the eye is nothing ele but a piece of the Optick Nerve, and therefore the motion is till continued thereby into the Brain, and by reitance or re-action of the Brain, is alo a rebound into the Optick Nerve again, which we not conceiving as motion or rebound from within, do think it is without, and call it Light, as hath been already hewed by the experience of a troake: We have no reaon to doubt that the Fountain of Light, the Sun, worketh by any other ways then the Fire, at leat
in this matter; and thus all viion hath its original from uch motion as is here decribed; for where there is no light, there is no ight; and therefore colour mut be the ame thing with light, as being the effect of the lucid bodies, their difference being onely this, That when the light cometh directly from the Fountain to the eye, or indirectly by reflexion from clean and polite bodies, and uch as have not any polite bodies, and uch as have not any particular motion internal to alter it, we call it light; but when it cometh to the eye by reflexion from uneven, rough, and coure bodies, or uch as are affected with internal motion of their own that may alter it, then we call it Colour; colour and light differing onely in this, that the one is pure, and the other perturbed light; by that which hath been aid, not onely the truth of the third propoition, but alo the whole manner of producing light and colour, is apparent.

As colour is not inherent in the object, but an effect thereof upon us, caued by uch motion in the object as hath been decribed; o neither is ound in the thing we hear, but in our elves; one manifet ign thereof, is, That as man may ee, o alo he may hear double & trebble by multiplication of Ecchoes, which Ecchoes are ounds as well as the Original; and not being in one and the ame place, cannot be inherent in the body that maketh them; nothing can make any thing which is not in it elf; the Clapper of a Bell hath no ound in it, but motion, and maketh motion in the internal parts of the Bell; o the Bell hath motion and not ound, that imparteth motion to the air; and the aire hath motion, but not ound; the air imparteth motion by the ear and nerve unto the Brain; and the Brain hath motion, but not ound; from the Brain it reboundeth back into the Nerves outward, and thence it becommeth an Apparition without, which we call ound; And to proceed to the ret of the ences, it is apparent enough, that the mell and tate of the ame thing are not the ame to every man, and therefore are not in the thing melt or tated, but in the men; o likewie the heat we feel from the fire is manifetly in us, and is quite different from the heat which is in the fire; for our heat is pleaure or pain, according as it is great or moderate; but in the cool there is no uch thing: By this the lat is proved, viz. that as in viion,
o alo in Conceptions that arie from other enes, the ubject of their inherence is not in the object, but in the Sentinent; And from hence alo it followeth that whatoever accidents or qualities our ences make us think there be in the world, they be not there, but are eeming and apparitions only; the things that really are in the world without us, are thoe motions by which thee eemings are caued; and this is the great deception of ence, which alo is to be by ence corrected: for as ence telleth me when I ee directly, that the colour eemeth to be in the object; o alo ence telleth me when I ee by reflection, that colour is in the object. But now I am out of the way from the outward Creation of Man, in whom there is a principle of more fine and reflexive reaon, which hangs on, though not in that manner, in the more perfect kinde of Brutes, as ence alo (loth to be curbed with too narrow compas) layes hold upon ome kinde of plants, as in thoe undry orts of Zoophyta, but in the ret there are no further footteps dicovered of an animadverive forme abiding in them; yet there be the effects of an inadvertent forme ( < in non-Latin alphabet > ) of materiated or incorporated Art or eminal Reaon; I ay it is no uneven jot to pas from the more faint and obcure example of Spermatical life, to the more Coniderable effects of general Motion in Mineralls, Metalls, nor yet to ay any thing of the Medicines extracted, mortified, fixt, diolv'd and incorporated with their proper Veagles, becaue we have intended it our lat buines to return to Mineralls, Mettals, and undry Meteors, whoe eaie and rude hapes have no need of any particular principle of life, or Spermatical form ditinct from the ret, or motion of the particles of the matter.

But there is that curioity of form and beauty in the more noble kinde of Plants, bearing uch a utablenes and harmony with the more refined ence and agacity of the oul of Man, that he cannot chooe (his intellectual touch being o weetly gratified by what it deprehends in uch like objects,) but acknowledge that ome hidden caue much a-kin to his own nature that is intellectual, is the contriver and perfecter of thee o pleaant pectacles in the world.

Nor is it at all to the purpoe to object that this buines of
Beauty and comelines of proportion is but a conceit, becaue ome men acknowledge no uch thing, and all things are alike handome to them, who yet notwithtanding have the ue of their eyes as well as other folks; for I ay, this rather makes for what we aim at, that Pulchritudo is conveyed indeed by the outward ences unto the oul, but a more intellectual faculty is that which relihes it; as an Atrologicall, or better, a Geometricall Scheam is let in by the eyes, but the Demontration is dicern'd by Reaon: And therefore it is more rational to affirm, that ome intellectual principle was the Author of this Pulchritude of things, then that they hould be thus fahion'd without the help of that principle: And to ay there is no uch thing as Pulchritude, and ome ay, there is no way to felicity; The firt, I anwer, is becaue ome mens ouls are o dull and tupid. And the econd is that they never knew The way to blis, The firt cannot relih all objects alike in that repect; The econd knows not Happines, nor the way to long life, nor the means to Health, nor how to return from Age to Youth, &c. which is as aburd and groundles as to conclude there is no uch thing as Reaon and Demontration, becaue a natural fool cannot reach unto it. But that there is uch a thing as The way to Blis, Long life, and a certain way to Health, not as yet known in England, I will demontrate in a Treatie by it elf; The way to Health I hall hew you anon in this book, the ret in another Part, as I promied you.

Now that there is uch a thing as Beauty, and that it is acknowledged by the whole generations of men, to be in Trees, flowers and fruits, and the adorning of buildings in all Ages, is an example, and undenyable tetimony; for what is more and ordinary with them then taking in flowers and fruitage for the garnihing of their work? Beides I appeal to any man that is not unk into o forlorne a pitch of Degeneracy; that he is as tupid to thee things as the baet of Beats, whether for example, a rightly cut Tetrae • rum, cube or Icoa • drum, have no more pulchritude in them, then any rude broken • one lying in the field or high-wayes; Or to name other olid Figures which though they be not regular properly o called, yet have a etled Idea, & Nature, as a Cone, Sphere, or Cylinder, whether the ight of thee
do not gratifie the mindes of men more, and pretend to more elegancy of hape, then thoe rude cuttings or chippings of free-tone that fall from the Maons hands, and erve for nothing but to fill up the middle of the wall, and o to be hid from the eyes of Man for their uglines: And it is obervable, That if Nature hape any thing neer this Geometrical accuracy, that we take notice of it with much content and pleaure, as if it be but exactly round, as there be abundance of uch tones upon Meque, a hill in Arabia, I have een them there, or ordinarily Quinquangular, or have the ides but parallels, though the Angles be unequal, as is een in ome little tones, and in a kinde of Alablater found here in England, and other pretty tones found upon Bulverton-hill neer Sidmouth in Devonhire; and neer Stratford upon Avon, and in Tyms Grove at Colton in Warwickehire, are found uch tones that grow naturally carved with various works, ome with Roes, others with Lyons, Eagles, and all manner of delightfull works; Thee tones I ay, gratifie our ight, as having a nearer cognation with the oul of man that is rational and intellectual, and therefore is well pleaed when it meets with any outward object that fits and agrees with thoe congenite Ideas her own nature is furnihed with: For Symmemetry, Equality, and Correpondency of parts, is the dicernment of Reaon, not the object of Sence, as I have in another place proved.

Now therefore it being evident, that there is uch a thing as Beauty, Symmetry and Comelines of proportion, (to ay nothing of the delightful mixture of colours, and that this is the proper object of the Undertanding and Reaon; for thee things be not taken notice of by the Beats) I think I may afely inferre, that whatoever is the firt and principal caue of changing the fluid and undeterminated Matter into hapes o comely and ymmetrical, as we ee in flowers and trees, is an undertanding Principle, and knowes both the nature of man, and of thoe objects he offers to his ight in this outward and viible world, and would have man earch and finde out thoe ecrets by the which he might keep his body in health many hundreds of years, and at lat find the way to Blis; for thee things cannot come by chance, or by a Multiranious attempt of the parts of the matter
upon themelves, for then it were likely that the pecies of things though ome might hit right, yet mot would be maimed and ridiculous; but now there is not any ineptitude in any thing which is a ign that the fluidnee of the matter is guided and determined by the overpowering counel of an eternall mind.

If it were not needlee, I might intance in undry kinds of flowers herbs and trees; but thee objects being o obvious, and every mans fancy being brauched with the remembrance of Roes, Marigolds, Gelliflowers, Pionies, Tulips, Pauies, Primroes, the leaves and cluters of the Vine &c. Of all which you mut confes that there is in them beauty and ymetry, and ue in Phyick, and gratefull proportion; I hold it uperfluity to weary you with any longer induction, but hall pas on to thoe coniderations behind, of their eed, ignaure and uefullnes, and hall pas through them very briefly, and then I hall come to minerall Medicines, thee obervables being very neceary firt to be known by way of an Introduction, and as ordinary and eaily Intelligible.

div.head: CHAP. VI.

argument.p: Of the Seeds and Signatures of Plants, and wherefore GOD made them.

div.p: EVery plant hath its eed; Roie Crucians therefore ay there are ecret Myteries lye hidden in them, which hould be our delight to find out; for Divine Providence made all good for the ue of man: And this being no neceary reult of the motion of the matter, as the whole contrivance of the plant indeed is not; and it being of great conequence that they have Seed for the continuance of propagation of their whole Species, and for the gratifying of mans Art alo, indutry and neceitie, (for much of Husbandry and Gardening lies in this) it cannot but be the Act of Counel to furnih the everal kinds of Plants with their Seeds, epecially the Earth being of uch a nature that though at firt for a while it might bring forth all manner of Plantts, (as ome will have it alo to have brought forth all kinds of Animals) yet at lat it would grow o luggih, that without the advantage of thoe mall compendious principles of generation, the Grain of Seed would yeild no uch births, no more then a Pump grown dry will yeild any Water, unles you pour a little Water into it firt, and then for o many Baons full, you may fetch up as many Tankards full.

Nor is it material to object that tinking Weeds, and poyonous Plants bear Seed too, as well as the mot pleaant and ueful; for even thoe tinking Weeds, and poyonous Plants have their ue in Roie Crucian Phyick, as you hall know hereafter; beides our common Phyick-Mongers often ue them as their Fancy guides them, grounded upon no other reaon then woful and deadly experience; ometimes the indutry of man is exercied by them to weed them out where they are hurtful, which reaons if they eeme fleight, let us but conider, that if humane indutry had nothing to conflict and truggle with, the fire of mans pirit would behalf extinguihed in the fleh, and then we hall acknowledge that that which I have alledged is not o contemptible nor invalid.

But econdly, Who knows but it is o with poyonous Plants, as vulgarly is fancyed concerning Toads, and other poyonous
Serpents that lick the Venom from off the Earth? So poyonous Plants may well draw to them all the Maligne Juice and nourihment, that the other may be more pure and defaecate, as there are Recepticles in the body of man, and Emunctories to drain them of uperfluous Choler and Melancholy, &c.

Latly, It is very well known by them that know any thing in Nature and Phyick, That thoe Herbs that the rude and ignorant would call Weeds, are the materials of very overaign Medicines, that Aconitum Hyemale, or Winter Wolfs bain, that otherwie is rank poyon, is reported to prevail mightily againt the biting of Vipers, Scorpions, and mad dogs, which Sir Chritopher Heydon aenteth unto; and that that plant that bears death in the very Name of it, Solanum Lethiferum, prevents death by procuring leep, if it be ayplyed in a Fever; nor are thoe things to be deemed uprofitable, ay the Roie Crucians, whoe ue our heavy ignorance will not let us undertand; but they will teach us as followeth.

We come now to the ignatures of plants, which indeed repects us more properly and adaequately then the other, and is a Key (as Roie Crucians ay) to enter man into the knowledge and ue of the Treaures of nature; I demand therefore, Whether it be not a very eaie and Genuine inference from the oberving that everal herbs are marked with ome mark or ign that intimates their vertue, what they are good for; and there being uch a creature as man in the World that can read & undertand thee igns and characters, hence to collect that the Author both of man and them, knew the nature of them both; and beides divine providence would onely initiate and enter mankind in the ueful knowledge of her Treaures by the Seraphical illuminated Roie Crucians, leaving the ret to employ the vulgar that they might not be idle; for the Theater of the World is an exercie of mans wit, and therefore all things are in ome meaure obcure and intricate; that the edulity of that divine park, the oul of man, may have matter of conquet and triumph, when he hath done bravely by a uperadvenient aitance of God.

But that there be ome plants that bear a very evident ignature of their nature and ue, for example, Capillus veneris, Politrichon, or Maiden-hair; the Lye in which it is odden or infus'd,
is good to wah the head, and make the hair grow in thoe places that are bare; the decoction of Quinces, which are a downey and hairy Fruit, is accounted good for the fetching again hair that hath been fallen by the French Pox; the Leaf of Balm and Alleluia, or Wood-Sorrel, as alo the roots of Anthora, repreent the heart in figure, and are Cordiacal.

Walnuts beare the whole ignature of the head; the outward green Cortex anwers to the Pericranium, and a Salt made of it is ingular good for Wounds in that part, as the Kernel is good for the Brains, which it reembles.

Vmbelicus Veneris is powerful to provoke lut, as Doctor Culpepper affirms; as alo your everal orts of Satyrions, which have the evident reemblance of the genetal parts upon them; Aron epecially, and all your Orchies, that they have given Names unto, from ome beat or other, as Cynoorchis, Orchis Miodes, Tragorchis, &c. the lat whereof notoriorious for its Goatih mell, and Tufts not unlike the Beard of that Lecherous Animal, is of all the ret the mot powerful incentive to lut.
The Leaves of Hypericon are very thick pricked, or pointed with little holes, and it is a ingular good Wound-herb, as ueful alo for de-obtructing the pores of the body.

Scorpioides, Echium, or Scorpions grae, is like the crooked Tayle of a Scorpion; and Ophiogloum, or Adders Tongue, hath a very plain and perfect reemblance of the Tongue of a Serpent; as alo Ophiocorodon of the intire head and upper-parts of the body; and thee are all held very good againt poyon, and the biting of Serpents; and generally all uch plants as are peckled with pots like the Skins of Vipers, or other venemous creatures, are known to be good againt the tings or bitings of them, and are powerful objects againt poyon.

Thus did divine providence by natural Hieroglyphicks, read hort Lectures to the rude wit of vulgar man; others of the Seraphically illuminated Fraternity, being entred, and ufficiently experienced of thee, found out the ret, it being very reaonable that other herbs that had not uch ignatures, might be very good for Medicinal ues, as well as they that had.

Roie Crucians have quickned and actuated their Phlegmatick natures to more frequent and effectual venery; for their long
lives health, & youthfulnes, hews they were not very fiery, to ay nothing of their happinee, riches, widom and vertue, becaue I have in my Treatie of The way to blie, poken of it largely.

div.head: CHAP. VII.

argument.p: Of the uefulnee of Plants, and of the Works of God.

div.p: YOu hal now briefly take notice of the uefulnes & profitablenes of plants both for Phyick and Food, and then pas on to the conideration of the inpired Roie Crucians, what their Medicines are: As for the common ues of Plants, Herbals teach you omething; but I refer you to the ingular Medicines of Roie Crucians in my Book of The way to blis for the alvation of your health, Animals know as much by intinct and nature; and that which is mot obervable here, is this, That brute Beats know as much as many Phyicians do that are taught by Herbals onely; and thee deny the power of God in the Works of Nature, and the power of Nature in the skill of man, that it hould be impoible to make Trees bear fruit in December, and Apple-trees to grow to bloom, and bear Apples contrary to kind in March.

Beats have knowledge in the vertue of Plants as well as men, for the Toad being overcharged with the poyon of the Spider, (as is well known) hath recoure to the Plantane-Leaf. The Weael when he is to encounter the Serpent, arms her elf with eating of Rue. The Dog when he is ick at the tomack, knows his cure, falls to his gras, vomits, and is well. The Swallows make ue of Celandine, the Lennet of Euphragia for the repairing of their ight. And the As when he is oppreed with melancholy, eats of the Herb Aplenium, or Miltwat & o eaes himelf of the welling of the pleen. The Raven makes ue of Cinquefoyle for the prolongation of his life to omtimes ix or evenhundred years; and therefore I think it is that the Roie Crucians precribe the oyle of Ravens, Swallows, and Harts for the ue of man to annoint himelf, to continue his fleh and well-complexioned body from wrinkles and lamenes; and Dictamnum Cretene is much ued, as I told you in my Wie mans Crown; Cretian Dittany cures Wounds of what nature oever.

Which thing I conceive no obcure indigation of providence; for they doing that by intinct and Nature, which men who have free Reaon cannot but acknowledge to be very pertinent and fitting, nay uch that the skilfullet Phyician will approve and allow; and thee creatures having no uch reaon and skill themelves as to turn Phyicians, it mut needs be concluded by vertue of that principle that contrived them, and made them of that Nature they are, enabled them alo to do thee things.

Let us now conider the Fruits of the Trees, where I think it will appear very manifetly, That there was one worker of Miracles, and inpirer of Roie Crucians; I might now reach out to Exortick-Plants, uch as the Cinamon-Tree, the Balome-Tree, and the Tree that bears the Nutmeg, invelopped the Mace; as alo the famous Indian Nut-Tree, which at once (as the Roie Crucians ay) affords almot all the necearies of life; for if they cut but the Twigs at Evening, there is a plentiful and pleaant Juice comes out, which they receive into Bottles, and drink intead of Wine, and out of which they extract uch an Aquae Vitae as is very overaign againt all manner of icknees, the branches and boughs they make their Houes of, and the body of the tree being very pongy within, though hard without, they eaily contrive into the frame and ue of their Canoes, or boats. the Kernel of the Nut erves them for bread and meat, and the Shells for Cups to drink in; and indeed they are not meer empty Cups, for there is found a delicious cooling milk in them; beides there is a kind of hemp that incloes the Nut, of which they make Ropes and Cables, and of the finet of it, Sayles for their hips; and the Leaves are o hard and harp pointed, that they eaily make Needles or Bodkins of them for titching their Sayles, and for other neceary purpoes; and that Providence may hew her elf benigne as well as wie, this o notable a Plant is not retrain'd to one coat of the World as the Eat-Indies, but is found in Affrica, Arabia, and in all the Ilands of the Wet-Indies, as Hipaniola, Cuba, where our men are victorers; and everal other places of the new-found World.

But I thought fit to init upon thee things by way of introduction, but to contain my elf within the compas of uch
objects as are neceary for our knowledge, and familiarly and ordinarily before our eyes, that we may the better (thee things undertood) take occaion from thence to demontrate the Roie Crucian way to health, and their ordinary Medicines which to us are not as yet known.

div.head: CHAP. IX.

argument.p: The Roie Crucian way how to get health; The caues why we eat food; Of the firt nature of the World; A meaure of raw and temperate meat, and the caue of the fiery, and oummy Gall and needles muddy bowels the melt; nature careles of making the reins of Urine drawers, drinkles animals have none at all; how to clene your elf from thee idle Bowels and avoid all dieaes.

div.p:
DO you not conider the weaknee of man, what faculties he hath, and in what order he is in repect of the ret of the creatures; Roie Crucians oberve though his body be weake and diarmed, yet his inward abilities of reaon, and artificiall contrivance is admirable; he is much given to earch out the Medicinall virtues of Plants, Wights, and Mineralls, and hath found out thoe that were of o preent and great conequence as to be Antidotes againt poyon that would o quickly have dipatched mankind, it were good for us to demontrate the Roie Crucian Medicines, now our land is afflicted with a icknes called the new dieae, of which all orts dye, without remedy, for none as yet have precribed a Medicine, for young men that deire to live, and for old men that wih for health, without which no life is weet and avory, then let us bend our elves to cure our brethren firt, and endeavour to hew the means (beides the commmon Collegian Doctors drenches, or Culpepers way, how every man may get and keep his health, that is omething trange but a vowed truth; the conent & equall (I mean agreeable to kind) temper & dulling our four firt beginnings, the taff of our bodies, for if this knot be
broken, & they loo towards their former liberty, they wax proud and trong, and fight, for their nature is together by the ears, and put us to pain, and lets the rule of nature, and this they call the dieae.

Then to handle one at once as our manner is, and will keep our cutom till, to keep our health and body in temper, eems no uch matter to me as the world would make it, even plainly impoible, when I know all the wayes and entries to let in dieaes and ditempers of the body, may by mall heed be toped and fenced.

Wee mut needs draw breath and eat meat; for the caue I hall peake of it in its place; and as this is not all clear and agreeable, o nature hath her leavings; and again labour and rest are needful, and perhaps we cannot chue but be moved in mind with joy, greife, fear, hope, and uch like paions, though the Stoick deny neceity, aith Des Carte.

By o many wayes and gat • s dieaes may enter, if they be not well watced and looked unto, which may be done in reaon, and hath been done often, as they aure us that have lived long without all dieae and icknees, as Iohn Harding relates of a Miniter called Iohn Macklaine to have continued for thee fourcore years lat pat together in health, & after his hair, teeth, eys & fleh renued, & became yong again, & uch like tories are to be found enough if we might tay to eek them; ome are contented for all but air and meat, but thee ay they have often eeds of dieaes lye hid in them unable to be foreeen or prevented, as we find thoe meats that make the finet hew, (as Wine and Sugar) and uch enticeing baites, to have hid in them mot hateful dieaes and dregs in the bottom; o the air when it eems the bet and highet, yet is ometimes infected and poyoned with venemous breath ent out and thrut into it either from below or from the cars of Heaven, and as the caue is hidden and unknown to us, o the hurt impoible to be avoyed and prevented.

If I lit to let my peech run at large, epecialy in other mens grounds, I could finde that that Diviion is fale, firt, (to come to meat anon) and then if it were
true, yet the caue of that infection not unable to be foreeen and warded; but I am o orry for the fault above, that I can the better take heed hereafter; yet methinks it is a grief to hear the harmles and glorious divine things above o defaced with tander, and no man makes anwer for them.

Gentle Reader, be pleaed to tay a little; If the Stars have no light, and o no power but from the Sun, that mot wholome and properous creature, then they hurt him mot wrongfully, and reprove themelves very rightly. And again, if they be but a piece of the finer part; and firt nature, as it were, of the World, as I have hewed in my Book of the The Wie Mans Crown, then they be the wholomet things in the World; o far be they from poyoned lander: And o let their Lights be never o groly mingled in their meetings, and thereby that tate of the Weather changed uddenly, and from thence our bodie's troubled and turned into Dieaes, becaue they were not prepared and made ready for it, yet the things are good and properous; and by knowledge of Atrology, or influences of the Planets, and races of the tars, we may prepare our elves, and prevent all, if we cannot have that happines to convere with our Guardian Genius. Now for lower reflexion, it is not worth the anwering when there is o much wate ground in the World; then let us pas over to that other Breach; may we not hun the leaving baits in our Dyet, and take uch meat as is mot temperate and near our Nature, and then dres the ame after the mot kindly and wholome manner, eaoning it well with labour, mirth and leep?

And to be plain, I have hewed in another Treatie of mine, entituled, The way to blie, o much noted by our Writers, what a jewel of health it were to ue all raw & temperate meat, or becau we be wie & vertuous, and this Dyet would perhaps change our Nature of fire, but like Philoophers, a quite contrary way; taking the bet, when as none is lot, and leaving the wort, which is that we now take, a Way I ay, to trip of all grosnes and foulnes of bodies, the only hurt of themelves, and is the Food of all Dieaes.

I will tell you another way which you will think trange, but you hall find it true; if the meat be temperate, as I bid you
chue it, there is no hurt can come thereby, (if you keep meaure in your elves) ave from your leavings; thee in o clear a Dyet firt will be very few; but if you would be ruled by my Counel which Nature taught me, thoe few hould never hurt you.

Of all the Leavings in the body, there are three which the liver maketh mot troubleome unto us, (for the ret are eaily dipatched) a light and eaie, or rather a fiery (as ome call) Choller; a cold and heavy mud, called Melancholly; and the third is Vrine, which I wil treat of in the next Chapter but thoe two the worer, and this fault is not in themelves, but all by reaon of the needles and hurtful bowels in our bodies, (as the Seeds-man ueth to ow good and bad together) which being of the ame kind and quality with thoe humors, do draw and pul them til unto them (as all other parts and things do) for their Food and nourihment and o by the narrow paages to and fro, their greedines in pulling and holding, and a hundred uch means, ubject to great michances, have brought in as many michiefs, whereas Nature the great expeller of her unlike, and Enemies, if he had free choice and liberty, would otherwie with cae, and without hurt, expel thoe Leavings, epecially o mall a number of the better ort in o clean a Dyet; nay, et the malice of thoe parts, (thoe parts are Melt-Gall, and Reins) if there be not ufficient tore of other oul meat at hand, like a poyoned or a purging Medicine, they ue to draw good Juices, and to make Food of them; what is not manifeted in this chapter, hall methodically be demontrated in the enuing, for I intend to be erious in this part of my Book, and will hew you what Nature taught me.

div.head: CHAP. X.

argument.p: Roie Crucian Medicines made plain by examples, and thoe are above controlement; That the wet Sun-beams declare ome fine and forrain fatnes to nourih mankind. How to live twenty yeers without Food, as many creatures do. Ve and Cutom a econd Nature: The Bird called Manuda Diaoa, and the inging Dog, and Camelian that never eat food. An experienced Medicine, and how to apply it, Paracele, and the Roie Crucian new Art of Healing.

div.p: OF Aritotle it is reported, That he is the witty Spye of Nature, and as if he had been made in this matter, he hews the need and ue of the greater Entralls and Bowels of Wights, and aith very truly and wiely, The Heart and Liver as the pring of Life and Food, to be needful for all VVights, adding to the hotter one, the Brain to cool, and the Lights to clene the Heat, taying there as if he thought the other three unprofitable; nay for one of them in the ame Book, (I ay) telling the tories of the Hart and Camel, and giving the reaon why they be both o wift, healthful, long-liv'd and other good properties above the ret enfeoffed, vouched in plain tearms, the want of the fiery and cummy Gall, as a great Enemy to them, for the Melt that muddy Bowel, that it may be left out as needles in the bodies of the better creatures. The Meadows near Cortinae and Muggadore declare when by a trange and hidden vertue they bereave the Beats thereof that graze upon them of it; the Herb is called Aplenium; as I told you in the preceding Chapters, nay, that the Milt is not onely idle, but hurtful, which all experience, even in our elves hath taught it.

The Turks light Footmen, (I ay, which I know not by what example unles it were the want of the ame in the Camel, making the Beat able to travel an hundred miles a day, and o without drink fifteen dayes together) being in their childhood purged of their Milt, prove thereby the mot light, wift, ound and lating Footmen in the World.

As for the veins of Urine-drawers, as drinkles creatures have none at all, o ome men have but one of them, as if nature paed not to make any at all; if we could forbear our drink (as thee Beats do by kinde, and ome men by cutom) we might the better pare them, and avoid many michiefs in our bodies.

Therefore the odd man, Paracelus, I know not by what light, if not of the Roie Cros, (cat in I think from eraphical illumination) not onely ees thee faults, but alo finds wayes to amend them, and to cut the michiefs off all thee three noyome parts, not with any yeilding Craft, but with Roie Crucian divine kind of Healing, with Aurum protabile, &c. o that to avoid all dieaes that pring of the Leavings, take of Aurum potabile, one ounce; one pound of the Oyle of Ravens; two pound of Miltwat, or Aplenium; a handful of Cinkefoyle, of Dictamnum Cretene, Ophioglosum and Scorpioides, Echium, of each a like quantity, and oberve the Acendent, and his Lord; and the Moon, and Lord of the ixt, at your dicretion, and take the quantity of a Walnut every night and morning, and anoynt the face & hands, & (if you wil) the ret of the body: Roie Crucians have other healing and yeilding Medicines, you hall know them in their places; this is uch an experienced Medicine, that you know where to find it; I need not hew you to put out the way and power of thee idle bowels, or perhaps it hould not need, and in a tock that eaeth our clean Dyet Nature her elf as he doth in thoe Meadows by other creatures would alo quite raze and dipatch them within a few generations.

But I will go further, Hear a Roie Crucian new and unheard of opinion, and yet let not your judgement run, before you ee good reaon; What if we could fat for ever, and live without all food? might not all hurt and danger of meat be then foretalled? if other Creatures, whoe life hangeth upon the ame hold, by the ufferance, nay by the commandement of God and Nature, do lat for ever, there is no Reaon but the ame common Nature will at lat uffer it in us; Let us ee. And to tep over the Camelion, becaue it is a Cold and bloodles Creature; what ay we to a Bird, which is an hot and perfect one? a bird in the Molucco Ilands, Manuda Diaca by name, that hath no feet at all, no more then an ordinary fih, as Mr. Moore aith, and I have een her; the bignes of her body and bill, as likewie the form of them, is much what of a Swallows, but the preading out of her wings and Tail has no les compas then an Eagles; he lives and breeds in the Aire, born up by the force of wind with more eae then Archytas his Dove, and comes not near the earth but for her Burial; for the largenes and lightnes of her wings and tail utain her without Laitude, and the laying of her Egges and brooding of her young is upon the back of the Male, which is made hollow, as alo the breat of the Female, for the more eaie incubation, taking no other food, as alas how hould he? then there is found: but whether he lives meerly of the dew of Heaven, or of flies and uch like inects, I leave to others to dipute.

Nay, have you not heard of the Little Dog in the Wet Indies, which ingeth o weetly all the night long, neither night nor day eating any thing? But there be examples in our kind as well, then it is certain above controlment: Sir Chritopher Heydon aith there is a Mouthles and o a meatles people or kind of men about the head of Ganges, which liveth by the breath of their Notrils, except when they take a far journey, they mend their Diet with the mell of flowers: and let you may think I lean upon bare Authorities without the tay of reaon, all the matter rets upon this reaon I told you before, that our life lay in the hand (beide a little exercie) of two like meats, one for the Soul and Natural heat which is within us, and the finet and firt moiture in our body, the others is without any meat, of the ame Temper with our body as near as may be; to uphold the frame and building of
the ame which I aid to be a fine Aiery and Fiery flame.

And we are now grown o out of order, and o much etranged from our Etherial firt Moiture and the life of God, that we creep downward towards the Earth through dieaes, before we can reach the Life of the Vehicle; within ixcore years we dye, and are hidden from the enible approch of renewing life.

div.head: CHAP. XI.

argument.p: Of Nature and her medicines experienced by Roie Crucians, and of the occult virtue of Myteries; of the healing and conuming medicines and of their ue; of the Gout, Leproie, Dropie and Falling Sicknes, &c.

div.p: NOW the Aire it elf, epecially when it is ever more as the wet Sunbeams declare, o prinkled with ome Fine forraign fatnes, may eem ufficient food to nourih the finer part of our Frame, wherein the temper of mankind, and his life (touching that point) tandeth, which is as much as any meat can do to life, (for it is not fed by common food, as I aid above) though not enough for trength, becaue the groer, ounder, and tougher parts wherein the trength lyeth, hall want food in this Dyet, and fail no doubt greatly, yet life hall lat till, as long as Aire and firt moiture holds, in my opinion: or if we think that o pare a Diet, we may mend it (as the mouthles people do) with mell of Flowers: or rather, as we know Nature is able to draw Aire and other food which he deireth through the skin into all places of the body; o if he had meat applyed to the tomach, he would no doubt atisfie herelf that way mot finely, without the heap of hurts let in at the broad and common gates, as we ee by example for Drink, that all the while we it in Water we hall never thirt And for meat, I have heard Roie Crucians ay, by applying of wine in this ort they fated without all hunger for two years together.

And in like manner I have experienced this, and fated two dayes when I firt tudied the nature of the Guardian Genii: But if that would not erve the turn, and we mut needs receive in
meat at the common gate, yet we may let it pas no further then the gate, and make the tomach in the mouth, which is the ue of ome Roie Crucians when they are Seraphically illuminated; and to provide enough for life and trength, and a great deal better for our health, then we do, becaue the clearer part alone hould be received, And moreover I ay, for the clear dipatch of that our ordinary trouble and anoyance which your reverence will not uffer me to name, although I might among Phyicians, but they know my meaning: But it hall not need to teal hifts and holds if you will believe the Roie Crucians, that we may eaily fat all our life (though it be three hundred years together) without all kind of meat, and o cut off all doubts and dangers of dieaes thereof pringing; and for my own part, I know ome that have fated and lived in the holy orders of the Fraternity without all food ten years pace together. What need we ay more? if you be both o hard of belief, and dull of ight, and reports of good Authors, nor my own experience will ink into you, nor yet can you ee the light of reaon hining before you, take here a few of ordinary matters in the life and ue of men, and weigh one with another; is it not as common in ue, and indeed needful, to pit, and avoid another nameles leaving? and to Drink but to leep epecially? If ome of thee, nay all may be pared, why not our meat alo? let us ee a little, and by example, becaue Reaon is both too long and too open to cavil.

To leave drink, which many have all their lives left; Elizabeth Drewe, a Devonhire Gentlewoman, is reported never to have pat, nor the whole Indian Nation. Sr. Iohn Heydon aith, he knew one that kept the nameles matter forty daies together. And although this anwereth not the quetion, yet it heweth the truth of the former Holy Story, for if in o foul and gros a thing as dyet is, he could o long want it, why not thee men for ever, in o clear and fine adiet, almot empty and void of all leavings? For the groer ort, which make up this foul and hameful one we left before, as you heard, and the finer in the paage from the Stomach through the former Gates were drawn all away to the Liver, as the like is ever in us and voided otherwaies. To cloe up all, I was at Sea with one that lept not one wink for thee three years lat pat, and Mr. Iohn Knotsford is a Witnes to this truth, and Capt. Windor.

And thus we ee thee trange things fall our in proof, but how I cannot tand to hew: Firt, nature uffers them, then ue and cutome another Nature brings them in, yet we may well beleeve the like in this matter of meat we have in hand; For as the Bear (according to the guie of many Beats that lurk in Winter) fateth fourty daies, o Eugenius Theodidactus, the reported Roie-Crucian tells of a Scottih young man, David Zeamons, that waited on him, that by ue brought himelf to fat three daies together, which by ue might have been three hundred as well, if he had ordered himelf thereafter by low and creeping cutome, as Captain Copeland calls it, and by uch means as I et down before.

So we ee, I ay, great wordly wonders prove plain and eaie truths in the ight of Widome: you have read of the wonderful works of God in the Acourate Structure of mans Body, of his Soul, of his Senes, of Plants, of Minerals; and Roie Crucian medicine hall be that which I will init upon, and that by the means aforeaid (where are more than one, if this like them not, they may take another) it is poible for all men by kind and cutome to keep their health for ever: Let us come to the next point, that is, awell to be recovered if it were lot, and that all dieaes may be cured. This is a point much harder then the firt, even o beet and topt with all kind of lets and incumbrances, that a man can carce tell which way to et his foot forwards.
