Firt appears Aeculapius, Hippocrates, and Plato, the chief among the Grecians, bearing in hand undry dieaes of both kinds (both come by decent, and gotten by purchae) hopeles and pat recovery, and giving over the men that owe them, for troubleome to themelves and to the Commonwealth: Then you may ee Galen, and his oft and fine Company with him, and that follow thee are Gerard and Riverius, and Culpepper, and thee with a long train of hedge-Doctours; and among thee tands Freeman, with Caterers, and Cooks, laden after them with all kind of dainty Druggs, tand forth and Cry, they have thee many ages devoured heaps of Books, and took endles pains in earching out the Nature of ingle Medicines, and making mixtures of the ame, and yet could hardly cure ome Agues, and other les dieaes; But for the four great dieaes, viz. the Gout, Leproie, Dropie,
Falling Sicknes, they could never heal them, and have therefore for Oracles et them down incurable.

div.head: CHAP. XII.

argument.p: That the knowledge and vertue of Medicines are ecretly hid from vulgar undertanding: how they may be gotten: and of what lies couched in the Oil of Bodies: of the ue, and how to fetch it out by Skill, the Haven of Medicine.

div.p: VVHat is left to be done in this Matter? what hall we et againt the weight of o many great mens Authorities? Equally put them in the Ballance, as we have done hitherto, and weigh them with truth and reaon: But where hall we find it? ay they; As it is every where, as Mr. Hobbs aid, drowned in the deep, o in this matter it is cattered all about, and largely pread withall; for there be three things, and every one full of under-Branches, belonging to the Roie Crucian Art and way of Healing; The firt is knowledge of the Dieaes, the econd the remedies againt them, and the third of the Appliance of the remedies, all which hould be travered in this Methodical myterious Treatie: but it hall not need I hope, nay we mut take heed how we enter into o long and large a race, in o hort and narrow a compas of time appointed, epecially being never run before by any man but our elf, not one of the wie Egyptians, nor our Ancetours, the holy Company of Moes and Elias, whoe teps we trive to follow, and their ucceours; for when they have once hit the mark they have hot at, and gotten the great and general Medicine Caput mortuum A. P. curing with eae all dieaes, they think it traight enough, and an empty and needles Labour, as it is indeed, to trouble themelves and their Children with large Rules about innumerable Signs and Caues of infinite dieaes, and about other mall particulars in appliance. Neither would I have you et Sendivogius, Paracele, and their heirs upon me, and ay they have taken great and goodly pains in this field; you will then force me to peak my thoughts.

Though thee men, (to let Philalethes, Vaughan, and Culpepper, Varlet, Freeman, and other Pretenders, with ome Schollars goe, as too young and childih yet,) by great light of Wit wherewith they flowed, and by long proling both with eies, ears, and hands, in the myteries of Egypt, aw and performed many of the Roie Crucian deep ecrets, yea and there got mot of their worldly praie, although I think a number feigned, yet Paracele his new Art and Rules of Healing are not good in my opinion; For firt, againt the example of the Roie crucians, from whom he had received all things, and then in depight and digrace of Galen, for micalling his Countrymen, as you have heard, but chiefly carryed away with a mad and raging deire of Fame and Honour, which Culpepper alwaies depied, yet the Starres favoured him, when I aited to et up that new, famous and trange work of Phyick, now well known and practied, which Paracele when he took in hand, a man unfit to do it, to pull down and raze the old Work, and to et up our new experienced ecret, which he could never do all his life.

Then we ee how it is performed, he ets down ome fale rules, ome wat, idle, and ome wanting, and all uncontant, diordered, and unlearned; when he doth well (as he doth ometime) he doth no more then was done before him, and brings in the ame thing diguied with new, odd, cros, and unheard of names, uch as may move wonder at the firt, but when they be canned, Laughter, as Mr. Moor aith of Eugenius Philalethes his like devies in his Aula Lucis Adamica Magica & Euphrates, and others of his Welch Philoophie. And that I doe not lander them where there is no caue, I could prove, if this place would admit a Volume. Wherefore let us follow the true and right Roie Crucians, as eaily you may know them by their actions, if ever you fortune to ee them and be acquainted with them; and leave Paracele, and the ret in this ill matter, and Light and Apih, as he makes it; and why hould we pend all our care and thought about a mall matter? you have a good Medicine and remedy againt dieaes, when old wives in the Countrey, and ome good Women, amongt other Dr. Culpeppers late wife, and Simple men, on our ide (I mean Simple in repect of the Grecian ubtilties about nothing) when thee people have healed mot, nay,
even all dieaes, and with which womanih Medicines indeed, the German Doctour (let us give him his due praie) hath quite lain the Grecian Phyick, and here done much for mankind, by decribing and dipatching our cloe and ecret enemie, which under colour of friendhip and fighting againt our enemies hath this long time betrayed us and done us much michief; which thing one of their bet Captains of their State, Fernell by name, after he had been a while in Egypt, began to mell at lat, and began to repent himelf of all his former pains (which we know were great) betowed in that kind of Healing, aying it to be but words, and the whole force and weight of this Art to lean upon the knowledge and vertues of Medicines, ecretly hid and couched in the midt and oyl of bodies, to be fetched out and gotten by the skilful means of Alchymits; even o of that Art, which is o much condemned of his fellows before and ince him, have fled and do daily flie from the daily toil and trouble of their fruitles and barren dead Sea: Now let us hift our Sailes, and flie further too, I hope of wind and tide and all; which we have.

But let us mount up to the main-mat top of our Knowledge, and ee if we can decribe the Haven of Roie Crucian Medicines, and ee what marks it hath, and how it differs from other Creeks adjoining, let at our journeys end we mis, with more hame and grief, and uffer hipwrack. A medicine is that which kills the face of that which hurts us; and this it doth many waies, and yet alo to one end (which is is the end of all doing and working as I aid before) for his food and utenance.

div.head: CHAP. XIII.

argument.p: Medicines againt Witchcraft, and to cure thoe that are afflicted thereby, although their bodies be poeed with evill pirits, that caue them to vomit up Needles, Thimbles, Pots, Glaes, Hair, and hreds of cloth, which by the Divil were conveyed into the body. That Winds and Tempets are raied by Witches upon meer ceremonies of Medicines, and of poyons; with the examples alo of other upernatural effects of unclean pirits, and of imagination. How to cure a Witch, and to take away her power.

div.p: A Servant of God and Secretary of Nature, mut be well advied of what he writes, epecially in this age, and of this matter (viz.) of the Roie Crucian Phyick, let he hould, as I aid before, fail in this deign, and o it may be a hame that he hould be reproved, by the pretenders to thoe wie truths he alone hath opened to publick view; then let us come again and ort our peeches.

A Medicine heals us, and kills our enemie, either by dulling or conuming it; for when it meets with a contrary of even trength (as when oyl and poyon &c. joyn) then in trength they neither eat up nor detroy one another, but both are dulled and weakned, and make one heavy thing which nature cateth out for an unlike and unkindly dead thing, which they call an excrement, or (Leaving;) but in cae it be of more trength and power then our enemie, then it quite detroyes, devours, and turns him into his own nature. And this conumer is either like the thing that hurts us, in which ort even as every herb of undry qualities draws and feeds upon his own juice in a Garden; o one Poyon doth cure another, and all purging and drawing things do heal us, and all Roie Crucians hid and Divine properties do work by plain reaon; or ele it is unlike and contrary to their cutome; after which manner as dry ticks, and Tow, and vinegar quench wild fire, or other Fat Fires, before water, whoe fatnes feeds it, for the trong contrary quality quelling and eating up the weaker; o doth any cold and dry thing as Bolearminick, Terra Lemnia, &c. cure a Rotten poyon: and o are a great number of cures done; which
onely coure, in a word, the Roie Crucians ue for Phyick, and not indeed without good ucces; we heard even now of two hinderances of healing, which our common Phyicians did take unawares, and Paracele pretends to have found out before me, gave any hint to the World of our experienced inventions, of Gold diolved and made potable, being incorporated with its proper Veyle, which we now ue by the name of Aurum potabile; but Paracele traieth much in the making of it, and knows it not no more than that tattered Doctor Freeman, o hamefully called amongt Phyicians: Whither in their poions, on the other ide, when they think all cures thereby performed.

Now when the Conuming Medicines have done their duties, Nature expells them for poion and unlike trange things, according to the Roie Crucian Axiomata, as well as the Grecian Rules, becaue all their Medicines were not approved by the Fraternity, and were by their confeion uch: But if they had either thought of the dulling nouriher, which as I told you, takes the nature of the leaving or excrement, or had known the Roie Crucian wholome Medicine, they would have made another reckoning; But let them go, and us ee out in time towards the Haven of Health, If the Art of Healing be nothing but detroying hurtful things, And their tronger enemies (but equality will ometimes erve the turn) or likes together; and the world be full of both thee kinds of Creatures, following the nature of their Parents of four beginnings, which are as we ee, ome like, and ome contrary one to another.

Then ure the Roie Crucian Art of Healing is not (as ome may ay) impoible, truly it wanteth nothing, but a man well skilled in the Nature of things, A ervant of God, and Secretary of Nature by name; for (I think) I need not put in a Phyician, to know what other part the Caues of the dieaes, which mut be known and matched, becaue as Sr. Chritopher Heydon the Seraphically Illuminated Roie Crucian, and learned Atrologer, well aith, He that knoweth the changes and chances of things in the great World, may oon find them in the Little.

But our nought-Healing Bill-men, that daub Medicines upon every Wall and Pot, and ome Leaches, will tep in, and ay, dieaes are in ome o great, and in all o many, and mans wit is
o weak and hallow, and the Medicines o hid and drowned in the deep of Nature, that it is not poible to find them all; or if they were found, to apply them with uch dicretion as Nature might abide thoe poioned Fraies and Battels within her. And again, admit all this untrue, yet there be ome dieaes ent from Witchcraft and Sorcery, and other means which have their caue, and o their Cure. I have read of om that have vomited uppieces of Cloth with Pins tuck in them, Nails, Needles, & uch like tuff; and this is ingeted into the Stomach, by the pretigious Sleights of Witches; Others I have een vomit up Hair, Glas, Iron, and pieces of Wood with Pins tuck in it; anothers Corps was diected, and ripping up the Ventricle, there they found the Caue of the dieae, which was a round piece of Wood, four Knives, ome even and harp, others were indented like a Saw. Others do Miracles by cating Flint-tones behind their Backs towards the Wet, or triking a River with Broom, or flinging of Sand in the Air, the tirring of Urine in a hole in the ground, or boyling of Hogges Britles in a pot; ome by whipering ome words in the Ear of an hore or wild Stagg, could direct him a journey according to their own deire. But what are thee things available? to gather Clouds, and to cover the Air with darknes, and then to make the ground moke with peals of Hail and Rain, and make the Air terrible with frequent Lightning and ratling Claps of Thunder: But this is from the power of the Divel (as ome fancy) which he hath in his Kingdome of the Air.

For the Remedy of thee michiefs, I have een a man was preent, when ome have vomited up Needles, Thimbles, Shreds of Cloth, pieces of Pots, Glas, Hair; another would uffer himelf for money to be run thorow with a word when I was not there, but it appeared to me a Fable. I have een a Roie Crucian Phyician cure thee afflicted People. But if you will ay, There is a touchtone whereby we may dicerne the truth of Metals, but that there is nothing whereby we may dicover the truth of Miracles recorded every where in Hitory. But I anwer there is, and that is this:
Firt, If what is recorded was avouched by uch perons, who had no end nor interet in avouching uch things.
Secondly, if there were many eye-witnees of the ame matter.

Thirdly and latly, If thee things which are o trange and miraculous leave any enible effects behind them; Though I will not acknowledge that all thoe Stories are fale that want thee Conditions, yet I dare affirme that it is meer Humour and Sullennes in a man to reject the Truth, of thoe that hear them: For it is to believe nothing but what he eeth himelf, from whence it will follow, That he is to read nothing of Hitory, for there is neither Pleaure nor any uefulnee, if it deerve no Belief.

Another Remedy for thee Supernatural dieaes, is, Let one watch the party Supected, when they go home to their houe, and preently after, before any body goe into the houe after him or her, let one pull a handful of the Thatch, or a Tyle that is over the Door, and if it be a Tyle, make a good Fire, and heat it red hot therein, etting a Trivet over it; then take the parties Water, if it be a Man, Woman, or Child, and poure it upon the red hot Tyle, upon one ide firt, and then on the other, and again put the Tyle into the Fire, and make it extremely hot, turning it ever and anon, and let no body come into the houe in the mean time.

If they be Cattle that are bewitched, take ome of the Hair of every one of them, and mix the Hair in fair water, or wet it well, and then lay it under the Tyle, the Trevet tanding over the Tyle, make a luty fire, turne your Tyle oft upon the Hair, and tir up the Hair ever and anon; after you have done this by the pace of a quarter of an hour; let the fire alone, and when the Ahes are cold, bury them in the ground towards that quarter of Heaven where the upected Witch lives; this Mr. Lilly aith he hath experienced.

If the Witch live where there is no Tyle, but Thatch, then take a great handful thereof, and wet it in the parties Water, or ele in common Water mixed with ome Salt, then lay it in the Fire, o that it may molter and mother by degrees, and in a long time: etting a Trivet over it. Or ele take two new Hore-hooes, heat them red hot, and nail one of them on the Threhold of the Door, but quench the other in the Urine of the party o bewitched, then et the Urine over the fire, and put the Hore-hooe in it, etting a Tryvet over the Pipkin or Pan wherein the Urine is; make
the urine boil with a little alt put into it, and the Hore nailes, until its almot conumed, viz. the Urine; what is not boiled fully away pour into the fire: Keep your Hor-hoe and Nails in a clean Cloth or Paper, and do likewie three everal times; the operation will be far more effectual if you do thee things at the very change or full Moon, or at the very hour of the firt or econd Quarter.
If they be Cattel, you mut mix the hair of their Tails with the Thatch, and moiten them being well bound together, and o let them be a long time in the fire conuming.

You have heard the Caue of ome of thee dieaes, and have heard the Cure by Sympathie alo; but thee are without the compas of Nature, and o let them pas with our fickle tanding, which is daily and hourely o beet with detinies, that a man can warrant nothing.

Truly detinies are o deep and bottomles, (to return traight Homer-like upon them, and therefore it were bet indeed to let them goe, and the applying of the Medicines with them) The rather becaue the other, (I mean the former) is o light a matter to a dicreet Phyician, uch a one as is pointed out by their old and famous Leader Hippocrates, who both in this and all other duties of his Art made uch peed, and o far paed all his fellowes (as none ince, which is a good time, could ever overtake him) no nor yet come o neer as to keep the ight of him, whom they had in chae and followed.

Then for thoe Supernatural caues, which I hall not tand here to earch (for o they are called) if they flow from unclean and wicked Spirits (as ome think) they are not the Stuff of the things that hurt us, though omtimes they dwell in and poes the body, but windy matters, much like unto thoe fierce and udden changes of the Weather, proceeding from the Influences of the Planets and fixed Stars, and working the like effects in mens bodies, o that ith the nearet caue is Natural, let the ret be what they will, and the Cure be done by Natural means, as we ee by experience amongt us: And therefore E. A. that pretends this, and puts the fault in the Faith of the wicked, which is a thing as far above Nature, yet holds its Cure with a Natural Medicine, which we call a Quinteence.

Although I am not willing, that ometimes this icknes is uch as he bids us ometimes withtand it with another as trong a belief et againt it, but for my part, I cannot reach it with my conceit (let deeper heads then mine or the Vice-Chancellor of Oxford, Doctor Owen, think upon it) how thee beliefs and imaginations, and other parts and powers of the oul or mind of man, can o flye out of their own kingdome, and Reigne over a forraign body, when we know the Soul and minde is o fat bound in the body indurance, and o like to be, untill it be the great pleaure of the Omnipotent and the Omnient God, the chief good, who hath committed them, to let them looe at once, and et them full at Liberty; and this may be diputed with Grace and knowledge on my part; Let this man therefore buzze againt my knowledge, which he would have to be more then Grace, I appeal to the Naturall faculties of any free judge, whether there be not as much Grace in me as there is honety in him: All men cenure as they like of Stories; o let them pas amongt old wives tales for me, we will everely follow our task. That if the effect do not ceae which the object hath wrought upon the Brain, o oon as ever by turning aide of the Organs the object ceaeth to work (viz.) though the ence be pat; As the troke of a tone, a blat of wind, puts tanding water into Motion, and it doth not preently give over moving as oon as the wind ceaeth, or the Stone etleth: o the Image or Conception remaineth, but more obcure, while we are awake, becaue ome object or other continually plyeth and olliciteth our eyes and ears, keepeth the mind in a tronger Motion, whereby the weaker doth not eaily appear. And this obcure conception is that we call Phantaie, or Imagination; Imagination being (to define it) conception remaining, and by little and little decaying from and after the act of ene, &c. If ome of thee dieaes pring, as Mr. Moore, Doctor Culpeper, and ome others hold, and with good reaon, from neither of both thee two roots named, but from a foul and venomous breath, ent forth from a poyoned temper of the Witches body, through the windines of hatefull eyes: For Thought fahioneth the blood and Spirits almot at his pleaure; then all the caues being ordinary, and agreeing to the coure of Nature, they may be cured and put to flight by the ame coure and means; which opinion, if you pleae to bear
with my tarrying, it is worth the handling, taketh hold upon this reaon, becaue (as Roie Crucians do witnes) ome beats of ranker venome, do witch and hurt after the ame manner; as an old Toad by tedfat view, not onely prevails, but benums a Weaell, but kills a young child. And by the ame means the Bever hunts the little fih, and takes his prey: But mot fiercely and michieouly of all creatures in the world, the two monters in kind, the Cockatrice and Apoblepas: again, for that the eye of a mentruous woman (as all report) doth pot the glas which it beholdeth; and moreover Eugenius Theodidactus, in the wiemans Crown, telleth of many folk that through a poyoned prerogative, which a montrous Mark of a double-ighted eye gave unto them, were able to bewitch to death all thoe upon whom that eye was angerly and urely et and fatned; but chiefly becaue we ee them that ue this wicked trade, to be by kind of a muddy and Earthlike complexion and nature, brought by age, as they be mot commonly long life, and gros diet, to the pitch of melancholy, that is, to a cold and mot dry nature in the world.

For certain proof whereof, bring one of them out of that beatlike life, brought unto merry company, and fed full with dainty Diet, and within twenty days, as hath by a Roie Crucian been tried a truth, the whole tate and nature of her body will be o changed, as it hall not uffer her to bewitch and hurt again; as you may read in my Familiar Spirit or Guardian Genius.

div.head: CHAP. XIV.

argument.p: The Naturall effects of Medicine: the force and power of mineralls in dieaes; with examples alo that every dieae-breeder hath the cure or remedy in it: examples that poyon prepared cures poyoned people: Roie Crucian Arts: the virtue and power of the Planets and heavenly Stars poured through the influence of the moon upon the Lower Creatures: of Hot Stomachs: of the Etherial firt moiture of of man: examples alo of Roie Crucian Natural and upernaturall cures: of the undertanding of thee experienced truths by the wit of man: of Paracelus and Culpeper.

div.p: LEt us come to the next and chiefet point; And there we mut not ay for hame, that thee helps and remedies lye hid in nature, too far for the wit of man to find, unles we will accue our own loth and dulnes: For nature hath brought them forth and laid them open awel as the Poyons and hurtful things, or ele he were very cros and ill-willing to him for whoe ake it eems he doth all things.

Nay further (as Mr. Hobs aith) her good will is uch, as he hath not only laid them open, but given us wayes to come by them, and means of peech, hands and wit alo, far above all other living creatures. And yet he hath not left us o, but let by chance we might go wide and mis them, to hew her motherly love and affection towards us, he hath guided (as Mr. Moor aith) many witles Beats, even by common ene, unto their peedy helps and remdies in their dieaes: That we by the plainnes and hame of the example (as Mr. Gadbury wiely aith) might be taught and moved to eek out the myterious truths of nature in Celetial bodies, as wel as beats that eek and find us Medicines helpful in the like dieaes, for our Terretial Tabernacle. As to name a few not unworthy meaning; he maketh the beat Hippotamus in time of his fulnes and fatnes to go to a reed, and by rubbing a vain to let himelf blood, and to top it again by laying mud upon it; A ick dog to eek an Herb and purge himelf; and the bear to do the ame after his long fat in Winter; he leads the Panther, when he is poyoned, to her foul and nameles
leaving; and the Tortoye, after he hath eat a Viper, to Summer Savery: And the Hedg-hog is o good a natural Atronomer, that he fortifies his hole againt foul weather; the Hog will gather Mos and traw to cover himelf a little before it rains; The dog knows the influence of Mars when he doth leep by the fire, and will not go out a dores when he is in any evil poition: and many uch like examples hath nature laid before us for our intruction; by which at lat wie Plato, Philo, Apollonius, Pythagoras, and painful men of Greece, as they themelves report, be they Elias or Eliha, from whom the order of the Roie Cros came, (as ome ay) or ele as others will have it, from Moes, or Ezekiel, or whooever, and by laying reaon and further proof together, firt made the Art and rules of Healing, to know whence dieaes came, and how to recover them. And then eeking all about for remedies to erve each turne, by little and little they matched the mot part of the leer rank with ingle Medicines, and the greater ones they doubled and coupled many together, inomuch as at lat, which was in Hippocrates time, they were able to heal all (aving four,) of the greatet and deepet dieaes, the Gout, the Dropie, the Leproie, the Falling icknes; which are now healed by the Roie Crucians onely. But this race is below the Seraphically illuminated Fraternity: now not a Phyician that is lined with Pluh in England, Spain, Germany, or France; but holds that Long-life, Health, Youth, not attainable, they therefore with one conent, amongt the other four, call them impoible.

But to come to the point; what wrong this was both to skill and nature, they do eaily ee and laugh at, which know that in this labour, they did not onely overee and skip the Minerals, the toutet helps in the whole tore-houe of Nature (although they could dig them out well enough to other and worer ues) but alo, which is in all, did let the Roie Crucian skill of preparing Medicines, whereby weak things are made almighty, quite ecape them.

Wherefore to make up the Roie Crucian Art of healing, and to make it able (as they ay) to help and cure all dieaes came in, or rather went before them, into mans body; The Egyptians in great avour too with nature both for their oil and bringing up,
o notably commended above all nations, (having for example, to move and teach them even the great weight of the world as Sr. Iohn Heydon aith) for wits to devie, and bodies to put in practie.

Whereby in hort time they unfolded the knot why the Minerals were of greatet force and power againt dieaes; and oon after, which was a divine light, and in-ight, they perceived the huge labour of eeking uch a huge ort of ingles and mixtures to be vain and empty, and pittiful among wiemen.

Becaue firt, there is nothing hurtful and a breeder of dieae, but it hath the heal and remedy for the ame about him: For the wings and feet of Cantharides, the Fruit of the Root Bezar, the Ahes of Scorpions, Toads, and Vipers; and divers other tronger poyons, both by nature and skill dret and prepared, do cure and heal their own and all other Poyons; nay as all tronger likes do cure their likes throughout the whole world of dieaes, even o when a man hath found out the thing that hurts him, he may by eaie skill mingle and break the temper of the ame further; that is, make it able to eat up and conume it elf as eaily, without any further doubt, toil and labour; But epecially becaue there is no one thing in the world, take what you will, that hath not the vertues of the Planets arreted and fatened upon it, and alo of the qualities thereof within it elf, that is not as good as all, and may erve intead of all, and that is not able to cure all dieaes; which thing weighed, and with dicoure of wit and reaon fully reached, they went to practie, and by the like harpnes of wit, they found out the kindly and ready way to dres and make fit thee three kinds of Medicines aforeaid, which contain all the Art of healing, all the ret are but wat words and grievous toyl, to tire a world of wits about a bootles matter, as aith Des Cartes. But epecially they reted in the lat, which is enough alone, and yet not without great forecat, to chue one of the bet, and that the very bet of all, for their eae in dreing. Though Dr. Culpeper of late was not content with this, but ran through the ret, awell to pite his enemies, the Colledge of Phyicians, as to make himelf famous in Taverns and Alehoues, as Paracele in his time did whoe teps he trove to follow againt the rule of Roie Crucian widom and vertue;
and the example of his ancetors.

But hath every thing all the vertues and influences taken from the Planets and Stars by the Moon, to the earth; That is, all the curing and healing power of all the things in the world? very well you mut remember that I proved above all the vertues and powers of heaven, poured down through the Influence of the Moon, upon thee lower creatures, to be nothing ele (as Captain George Wharton truly aith) but one elf ame life and Soul, and heavenly heat in all things, And again, that all dieaes flow from ditemper, and as it were dicord of the Natural conent of the body; then that thing which is endued with tore of life, and with exact and perfect temperatenes, eated upon both a ubtile and trong body, (which the thing in the bottom is) able alone by ubduing his weaker enemies, thoe ditempered dieaes, by trengthening his fellow life, Aurum Potabile, in our bodies. And latly, by orderly binding together the frame that was lipt out of order, to do as much as all the powers and forces of all the Plants, Weights, and minerals in the world, that is, to put to flight all trouble of dieaes, and retore the body to perfect health and quiernes.

But how is all this done? we talk of high things, and huddle up too many great matters together. It were good for us to work them out ditinctly; when this Aurum Potabile we peak of, and trong tempered medicines, lip into the tomach, it tayes no long digetion, being already digeted, nor look for any ordinary paages to be opened unto it, but as oon as it is raied out of leep by his fellow, the natural heat, by and by he flyes our, and skowers about, as fat as the Dolphine after his prey, or as nature her elf, whom Mr. Booker, as I take it (aith) to pierce bounds, and all to the purpoe, that is to eek his like food, and utenance, whereby to preerve his tate and being, which is the purpoe of all things in the world, as was aid above.

Now there is nothing o like and neer a perfect temperature in the world, as the Etherial firt moiture in man; But what this is, you may read in my book entituled < in non-Latin alphabet >
Ventus magnus.

This is bet and mot in the heart, the root of life, then thither it hyeth and preyeth upon that part firt, and that is the caue why
it preently retoreth a man half dead, and as it were, pulls him out of the throat of death; then it runs to the ret all about, increaing by that means the natural heat, and firt moiture of every part of the body; when this is done, he turns upon the parts themelves, and by encountring with them in the ame ort, according to his might, feeds upon them, and brings them a certain way towards his own nature, even o far as we will by our uage uffer; for if we take it with meaure and dicretion, it will bring our body to a middle mean and tate, between his own exact temperature and the ditemper of dieaes, even a better tate then ever it had before; if we ue it out of meaure, it takes us up too high, and too near his own nature, and makes us unmeet for the deeds of the duties of an earthly life. But in the mean while in the midt of this work, we mut know that by his exceeding heat and ubtlenes which is gotten by Roie Crucian skill, and which make up the trength above all things, it divides and catters, like moke before the wind, all ditempered and hurtful things, and if they cannot be reconciled and turned to goodnes, nature throws them out as dead, and unfruitful leavings.

But how do we talk, (as Mr William Tub the Atrological Fencer aith) o much of exact and perfect temper, when by the verdict of all the Quet in thee caes there is no uch thing found in nature, but in heaven onely? neither heard you me ay that it floated aloft, but was unk to the bottom of all nature; notwithtanding by a true and Holy Roie Crucian to be ounded and weighed up. For as heaven was once a gros and ditempered lump (as I told you in my book of the nature and dignity of Angels) by the divine art of God that ordered all things (as you have read in the Introductory part of this book,) refined and undred away round to the place and nature where it now tandeth; even o one of our gros bodies here below, being a piece of the ame lump alo, and all one with that which Heaven once was, may by the like art and cunning be refined and parted from all his ditempered dros and foul droines, and brought into a Heavenly nature of the bet and goodliet thing in Heaven: And yet you mut not take me as though I would have <…> wit of man, which is b • t a park of the divine g •
<…>
in my book called Ventus Ingens) to be able to reach the excellency of his work, and to make o great perfection; if he do but hadow it, and make a Counterfeit, that is, if he reach not o far as to make all things, but to mend a few by this his Heaven, all is well, it is as much as I can look for at the hand of any man that is not a Roie Crucian. Now is the time to ret a little, and pray for the good ue and practice of thoe that hall read our writing.

div.head: CHAP. XV.

argument.p: Of the Roie Crucian Sun, or Spiritual Oyl. Of the Divine Works of God not yet oberved. How we make Aether. Examples of Medicines Roie Crucian and Grecian. Of Poion. Of the Supernatural Miracles of the Roie Crucians, with obedience to Reaon. Another Medicine of Supernatural effect. Of the power and ecret skill of Nature. How to diolve Minerals: And how to prepare them for Mens Bodies.

div.p: EUgenius Theodidactus hath hewed you this Heaven, Nay this Sun of ours, which is nought ele, as I told you in one of my books of Atrologie, but an Oyl full of heavenly Spirits, and yet in Quality of his body jut, even and natural, fine and piercing, cloe and lating, able as well to rule this little World, as Mr. Thomas Heydon aith, the great Sun is able to governe the great World.

But what is he, aies Mr. Iohn Cleeveland, that can ee this Divine Art and Way, whereby God made his great and mighty work, viz: < in non-Latin alphabet > as I hewed in my Book, intituled, Moes peech to God, upon the econd chapter of Geneis? or if he aw it, learne and match it by imitation? I anwer, None but Roie Crucians, to whom I am a friend, and they God hath enlightned and unealed their eyes, they have found the way lying open in all places, and in all Natural changes, they ee them pas and travel, I ay till, the coure that Heydon calls oft and witty, that is, kindly eparation: and if he be not wift and rah as many, uch as Thomas
Vaughan and Street, but will have ober patience, his own skill and labour will be but little if he pleae; for Nature her elf very kindly will in her due time performe all, and even all that heavenly workmanhip be eaily performed; and yet I mean not o but that Art mut accompany and attend upon Nature (though with no great pains and skill) both forward and backward in this Journey (Doctour French knows my meaning, o doth Doctour Owen, if his angry Cenure will uffer his Natural judgement) until he come to his wihed ret, and to the top of all perfection.

If you perceive not, conider the way whereby we made our Ether in our book abovenamed, and matched our own firt moiture, a thing Etherial, I ay, and almot Temperate; mark what I ay, there is a further end in the matter, hold on the ame means whereby you came o far through The wie mans Crown, and are gone o far in the Way to blis, which is that I pake of, and you may reach it.

Then you ee the way to cure all dieaes by the third way of Egyptian healing, which they doe, and we may well call it the Egyptians Heaven, and yet it is a way far beneath the Roie Crucian Art of Healing, as we hall hew hereafter.

But if they will not yeeld yet to reaon, but mutter til Thomas Street-like, that thee Heavenly Medicines of ours are very high for the reach of mens illy wits, here trowed below upon the ground for other leer and baer ues, and that no man ince the firt man, or if I will ay Moes, was the firt, that firt found out thee inventions as they call them, after Adam; and that none but the ucceors of Moes have been ever yet known to have found and wrought the ame; I will not tand to beat reaon into uch giddy-braindmen, but go to the other two waies of healing, which the Egyptians found out and ued, and called the firt Mineral Medicines, and thee Moes taught the children of Irael in the valley of mount Sinai, when he took the Golden Calf which he had made, and calcined it in the fire, and ground it to powder, and incorporated it with a Solar Veagle, and made the children of Irael drink Aurum potabile.

And the next myteries and ecrets, as may appear by Riverius his peaking of Roie Crucian Secrets, we fitly may call this econd,
kind, becaue that is too large a Name (if it be lawful for us as well as for all other Learned men, where a fit word wants to make a new) we may do well I ay to call it a Cure it elf, becaue it is by that way of healing, whereby every elf ame thing further broken may cure it elf; and this inward and hidden thing as they ay, the outward and apparent by the coure of kind, whereby the tronger like eates up in triall and conumes the weaker.

If this leave be once granted, we will borrow a little more for the other two likewie, becaue their names, are not pertinent to our purpoe, and call that Heaven a Cure-all, for o it doth, and the next a Cure-the Great, becaue the Order of the Roie Crucians is alwayes to match the greater and more tubborn ort of dieaes with the Stout and mighty minerals, and the ret with thoe hidden cure-themelves, or at leat in the lower rank of lighter dieaes, with their likes, onely raw, as the Grecians ue them, without any curious dreing.

Let us draw nearer a concluion of the matter; becaue Grecians themelves are able, and our Englih Phyicians that learn of them, to cure the lighter ort of dieaes, and to heal all but the four aforeaid, we will leave the ret for them, and o let this econd kind of healing go called our hidden cure themelves, and bend all our batteries againt thee four which they call incurable, and ee how by force of our Mineral Medicines, they may be cured: we ee the Poyoned pirits and breaths of venomous things, with what force they work upon our bodies, things in Nature et againt them, and how they conume them; If you do not ee by imagination, reaon with your elves, if not remember thoe above named, that killed with their ight; Hear one or two more that work the ame by touch as violently. The Hare-fih, a mot cold and dry creature (to omit that he maketh a mans head ake by ight) if you touch her aloof onely with a taffe, that her venomous breath may go traight and round unto you, you die preently. The root Baazam in Paletine, as Pythagoras writes, kills the man that handleth it, and therefore they ued to make a dog pull it up (as Ben. Iohnon aith) who thereby died imediately. To come into the body; that cotly poyon Mr. Linacre talks of, that is in Nubia, and one grain kills a man out of hand yet tay but a quarter of an hours working, and that one grain divided will
overcome ten men; I hope you doubt not but thee mighty poyons if they were like in Nature to the four great dieaes, and by little and little to be born by Nature, and et upon them, would be able eaily, by their great trength to devour and conume them; or ele ure uch heaps of poyon as the Phyicians give us would not dwell o long within us, but would put out life in a moment. Now what are thee poyoned Vapours, but mot cold and dry bodies, wrought and broken up by naturall mingling, unto great finenes and ubtilenes, by this peircing wiftly all about, and by thee contrary qualities overcoming? Then let us take the toutet Minerals, uch as are called Middle Minerals by Roie Crucians, or hard juices by Mr. Berkenhead (to leave the Metals for a better purpoe) be they poyons, as G. Agricola aith, but what they be I care not, and after we have by meer working, cleaned them and tripped them of their cloggs and hinderances, broken and raied them to a fine ubtance, then match them with their likes, the hurtfull things in our bodies, hall they not let all the ret alone, and traightway cleave to their fellows, as well as a purging medicines, and o devour and draw them out by little and little? If there be no likes, I grant they will as well as that, fall upon their enemies, or good juices, and feed upon them.

Then what do you doubt is not a Mineral body far better? And therefore if it be raied to as great a finenes, much tronger in working then the gentle and looe temper of a wight or plant: wherefore thee our Mineral Medicines, and ome other forementioned Medicines, and cure the great, as we call them, hall in any reaon, work more violently upon their likes, then the natural poyons of Wights and Plants do upon their contraries, both becaue the like doth more eaily yield then the contrary, and for that the lighter here is the tronger.

But if you cannot ee thee things by the light of mind, open your eyes, and cat them a little into the School of Alchimy, into the leer and lower chool, I mean of Germans, and you hall ee the Schollars, epecially the maters, by tripping the Minerals, and lifting up their properties, but a few degrees, to work wonders; as to name three or four, by quenching the Loadtone in the oyl of Iron, his proper food, they make him ten times tronger, able to pull a nail out of a pot, &c. And by this natural pattern they make
Artificial drawers, not for Iron onely, but for all other things, yea and ome o mighty, as they will lift up an Ox from the ground, and rent the arm of a Tree from the body, as Mr. Comer doth witnes; who reporteth again that he aw a fleh-drawer, that pulled up 100 weight of fleh, and a mans eye out of his head, and his Lights up into his Throat and choaked him. They make binders alo to glew two pieces of Iron together, as fat as the Smith can joyn them To be hort they make eaters alo, that will conume Iron tones or any hard thing to nought in a moment; they diolve Gold into an oyle; they Fix Mercury with the moke of Brimtone, and make many rare devies of it; And all thee wonders and many more they do by certain reaon: I could tell you, if I could tand about it. In the mean time conider, if thee or any other uch like Minerals were raied higher, and led to the top of their finenes and ubtlenes, and matched with their like companions, or with their contraries, if you will, thoe great dieaes in our bodies, what tirrs they would make among them, how eaily they would hew them, pierce, divide, wate, and conume them? But you mu • alwayes have a pecial regard, that the Medicines be not liker our natures, then the nature of the thing that hurts us; for then they would firt fall upon us, and let the dieaes alone, which heed is eaily taken in minerals, things very far off our nature, aith Des Cartes.
And with thee experience the wonderful vertue of the oyl and water of Tobacco wie men I have known do miracles with it.

What is to be aid more in thee matters? I think nothing, unles through the countenance of an idle opinion that reigns among them, they dare flye to the lat, and of all other the mot lender helter, and deny our ability to break, tame and handle as we lit, uch tout and tubborn bodies: (what) becaue you know not how to do it, will you fahion all men by your mould? wie men would firt look into the power and trength of skill and nature, and ee what they can do and meaure it thereby, and not by their own weaknes; there hall you undertand, that there is nothing in nature o trong and tubborn, but it hath its match at leat, if not his overmatch in Nature, uch is the nature of mans body, of his Soul of ignatures of Plants, of mettals, and minerals, and other things alo.

But admit omewhat weaker as Herbs and Plants, &c. yet this, if he get the help of a wiemans Art unto him, hall quickly wax great and mend in trength and be able eaily to overcome, that other; mark how the dregs of Vinegar, a thing prung out from a weak beginning, and it elf as weak as water, is able if it be but once ditilled, to make touter things then minerals even mettals themelves, all but ilver and gold, to yield and melt down to his own waterih nature, nay which is more then Mild-dew of Heaven, as Mr. Cooks the Vicar calls it, wrought firt by the Bee that cunning beat, and then, twice or thrice by the ditiller, ditilled will do the ame, you may judge with your elf, what not onely thee, but other fiercer and harper things, as Salts, &c. more like to do upon Minerals; and by the way conider, if uch mild things as wine and honey, o meanly prepared, are able to ubdue in that ort the mot tiffe and tough things in the world, o minerals cheaper then Aurum Potabile, in their highet degree of dignity would cure the toutet dieae (being prepared fitly) that can grow in our bodies. Now let us it and take our ret a little and then we will conclude our Roie Crucian Medicines.

div.head: CHAP. XVI.

argument.p: How the Roie Crucians make a Chirurgeons intrument; that it hall pierce through any part of the whole body, without ene or feeling, and ound the depth of a wound. The difference of Common Phyicians Raw, Blunt, and herby medicines, and Roie Crucians: What a Phyician ought to be, what they ought to learn, and what they ought to practie, and then I hall love them of the order of the Roie Cros.

div.p:
BUt I wear away time in vain, to peak o much about tis matter; and yet ith all are not of like Capacity, I will adde one yet familiar example; when a Surgeon goeth about to earch a wound that is deep, if he thrut at it with a Butchers prick he would move Laughter; let him take a Thorwe, and it wil pierce omewhat prettily; but to do it throughly, and at his pleaure he will ue, (though to the great grief of his Patient) a fine and long intrument of Mettal. But a right Surgeon the common ones are but Butchers, uch a one as is a Phyician, and Atrologer, nay a Roie Crucian alo, would touch his Intrument, with a Loadtone, that is commonly found, to make it pierce throughout the body without all ene or feeling; Even o good Phyicians uch an one, as the Lord Marques of Worceter had, whom he taught many fine inventions: he told me of a Golden ball that this Lord made, that let him throw it into a River or Pool, it would arie aagain from the bottom at what hour he pleaed. This noble Marques hewed me a key of the lock, that would tell him who touched it. Nay if it fortuned to be pickt he could know who did it, and what was taken away (before their faces) and many rare things I have een this princely Philoopher do, which his excellency was pleaed to hew me; uch as thee are hard to be found in this Government, where none of thee can live without great envie. If one of thee Roie Crucians be to encounter with our greatet enemies, thee four we peak of, he would not I hope, if he were a true Roie Crucian be o mad as to thrut at them with the Raw and
blunt Herby Medicines uch as Dr. Scarborough, precribe, no nor although they be harpened by Iacob Heydon, by plain ditillations: neither would he, I think for pitty, ting the poor patieni with Eugenius Philalethes Martyrdome of rude and rank Minerals, and unles they were made into a fine clean natural and temperate quality, which would work mightily, and detroy either of thee four great dieaes, Leproie, Gout, Dropie, and Falling icknes: but feed, Comfort, or at leat not offend, and hurt his patient; they labour in vain that practie otherwie. Thee are the medecines which I onely ue, and which a good and wie Phyician ought onely to eek and follow, and if he cannot find it, let him ue the cure themelves. But uch a thing as this; I ay, brought to this equality, and finenes of frame and temper, (were it at the firt, wight, plant or mineral) was it which our father and founder Moes, (the chief of the Roie Cros) aid is like to Heaven, and the trength of all trengths piercing and ubduing all things.

This was it that warranted his Sons the roie Crucians to avow o toutly, that Art was long and Life hort, and all dieaes curable, when Hippocrates the Father of Common Phyicians, was driven by the infirmity and endles matter of his weak body, and envious mind tinctured with Covetounes, and fickle Medicines, to cry to Roie Crucians, but they would not hear uch hard-hearted Fellows, nor give him long Life, he aid therefore that Art was long, and Life was hort. And whereas he and his off-pring were fain to leave many dieaed helples, to the great hame of Art and Plague of mankind, is it any marvel when as they prick at them (as I aid) with a Butchers-prick? Nay, ee what they do by their practice, they be o far from all help and comfort to the Patient in greatet danger, that they increae his wier eys many waies, except the great eaer of all pain, and their common Medicine Death, be quickly adminitred: Firt, they make the Patient uffer the punihment due to their own lothful Idlenes, burdening his tomach with that labour of loonening and undering the Fine from the Gros, which they hould before have taken into their Glaes: and then by doing thee often, they clean tire his feeble Nature (as it would tire a hore) when as by tripping the foul and gros tuff, that dulls the working, and reteining the
Vertue in a narrow trong body, they might doe as much at one time as they doe now in twenty, and becaue their Medicines applyed are of maller power and weaker than the things that hurt us, they feed nourih and trengthen the dieae and icknes, but for all this if ome of this company and ide of Leeches have been and are yet ometimes able to heal all dieaes in our body (though with much ado, as you have heard) ave the four named remediles, yea and thoe awell in their pring as before their ripenes, as they themelves report. Is there any Proportion in Geometry? Let the College of Phyicians lay meaures why the Roie Crucian mighty Medicines which I call Cure-the-greats, paing thee in power, as much as the ripenes of a dieae is above the Spring, hall not overmatch the ripe as well as the green Dieaes: Wherefore there be no doubts left, but this plainly true, That albeit the Grecians is weak and halting in this kind of healing, yet is the Egyptian, or (as now they terme it) the Paracelians and Mineral skill ufficient to cure all dieaes: Then I have paid the whole umme of my promie, touching the econd means and helps to Blis and Happines, which is Life and Health.

Before I cloe, I think it very meet, while the time and place very fitly erveth, to do a good deed, and this hall be my intent to admonih and exhort the Grecian Leaches, and their Scholars the English, Spanish, and French Phyicians, whom if they follow Hippocrates, Plato, Pythagoras, and his fellows, I love for their Learning, and pitty for their mileading others (although it be grievous, I know to old Scholars, wone in a kind of Learning, to unlearne all as it were and begin again, for their own Credit and Virtue, yea and profit ake alo, if they eteem that bet, to leave thoe Gilded Pills and Sugred Baits, and all other crafty nares, wherewith the World hath been o long caught and o long tormented, and to eek this onely heavenly Society; as (to you that are learned) eaily may temper your elves, and be acquainted with the ready, true, plain and certain way of Healing dieaes. I think in former time they were not greatly to be blamed and accued but of dulnes and weaknes of undertanding, in not applying and eeing this perfection, and upplying of all their wants; but ince they have been o often warned not
with words only, but with examples of Learned men, Matheolus Fernelius, Severinus Danus, Philo Iudaeus, Diodorus Siculus, and other uch like which have and doe revolt, and flie away from them daily, yea and by the certain deeds of Paracele, it were imqity to it till: Well, few words will erve to wie and vertuous Phyicians, uch as are of themelves forward.

But there is another, and I am afraid, the greater ort, les honet, more Idle and Covetous, full of windy Pride and Words, but empty of all good learning, and they are no friends to Roie Crucians, nor they to them, and thee no gentle warning of any, no though a Roie Crucian himelf hould come and bring Truth her elf along with him in peron, would prevail: who care not it eems if half mankind hould perih for want of help and uccour, rather then loe their gains; And which not onely peak foully but write foolihly, againt this overflourihing vertue, but alo like the giddy people of my time, where they catch the State, banih the men that hold and poes it; whereas if it were a good Commonwealth (quoth Aritotle) the matter would be o far from Banihment or Imprionment, as they would eteem uch a man as well as the Laws (for he is himelf a Law) exempt from all obedience, and judge him worthy to be followed and obeyed as a perpetual King.

This untowardnes and crookednes in men cauod all our Alhealing Ancetors the Roie Crucians from time to time, never to abide their Sentence, but to the great hurt and los of mankind go into willing Banihment, you have etablihed a kind of Government among you (to purue the ame, like a little —) wherein you rule alone over the weak and orry ubjects of mens Bodies, then their health and afety you ought to eek onely, beides enough to maintain a contented etate alo, which Plato allowes his Governours, and not profit only (that were Tyranny) both for humanity and Religion ake, for to omit Religion, which they do lightly omit, if a Phyitian begin once to make a prey of men, he is not onely no man, but a mot Fierce and cruell Beat, not fit to be compared and matched and matched any where, if you eek all over the world as with the mihapen monter of India, which Aritotle decribes, and calls Martichora, which being by nature or cutome, I know not whether,
very greedy upon mans fleh, is with manifold and wonderful helpes furnihed, and armed unto it.

Firt with a face like a Man, a voice like a Trumpet, two fit things to allure and call him in) and then if he flye, with the wiftnes of an Hart to overtake him, he darts like a Porcupine, to wound him afar of; and with the tail of a Scorpion, as it were a poyoned haft, near hand to ting him: furthermore, let all this might not erve, by occaion of Armour, he hath feet like a Lion, fiercely and cruelly to tear him, and three rowes of teeth, on each Chap for the in devouring. Apply you and the Apothecarries, the ret your elves, in ecret for my part, as I am not a Roie Crucian, o I am as well as they, orry to ee evil done. And I am loath to peak evil of it, and ure were not the great grief and envy I do bear; and alwayes did, to ee deert trodden down by uch unworthines, and ome little hopes I have to hear of the amendment, and o of the return of the truth, and good men out of banihment and imprionment, you hould have found me in Wetminter-Hall: as I have been an Atturny in Terme time, and mean to continue my practie there o long as I live, except in the Vacation, which I intend to pend in Chimical and Roie Crucian Medicines for the good of honet plain meaning men and my elf Eugenius Theodidactus.

But ome may ask what I mean by R. C. the Ceremonie is an Ebony Cros, flourihed and deckt with Roes of Gold, the Cros typiies Chrits ufferings upon the Cros for our ins, the Roes of Gold hew the Glory and Beauty of his Reurrection from death to life. And this is carried to Meque, Cacle, Apamia, Chaulatean Viria Caunuch, Mount Calvery, Haran and Mount Sinai, where they meet when they pleae and make Reolution of all their Actions, and then dipere themelves abroad, taking their pleaure alwayes in one of thee places, where they reolve alo all quetions of whatoever hath been done, is done, or hall be done in the world, from the beginning to the end thereof. And thee are the men are called Roie Crucians.
